form.definition: noun T or t is the twentieth letter of the alphabet.
to a T If something is done to a T, it is done exactly or with complete accuracy. He carried out the instructions to a T.
interjection In very informal language, ta means 'thank you'.
noun A tab is a small flap or loop attached to something to make it easier to hold or to fix in place. I hung my shirt up by the tab.
noun A tab is a small patch or label on something to identify it. The name on the tab showed it wasn't my towel.

keep tabs on If you keep tabs on someone or something, you watch them closely and check on what is happening. Could you keep tabs on the children while I pop out? I've been keeping tabs on the renovationsthey should be finished in another couple of weeks.
pick up the tab If you pick up the tab, you pay the bill for something. I'll shout this roundit's my turn to pick up the tab. The insurance company will pick up the tab for the repairs.
noun A tabby is a cat that has brown or grey stripes in its fur.

noun A table is a piece of furniture with a flat top which you use for putting things on. We eat our breakfast at the kitchen table. ...a dining table. ...a coffee table. ...an occasional table. We all sat round the table and discussed what to do.
noun A table is a set of numbers or facts arranged in rows and columns. This table shows the capital cities and the currencies of the different countries in the world.
verb If you table a proposal, you put it forward formally for people to consider. Two amendments to the bill were tabled in this morning's session of parliament.
table of contents A table of contents is a list at the beginning of a book which tells what is in it and what page each thing is on.

turn the tables If you turn the tables on someone, you completely reverse the situation so that now you are in a better position than them. Italy turned the tables in the second half, scoring two quick goals over Hungary.
noun A tablecloth is a piece of fabric or plastic that you put over the top of a table to prevent it from getting stained or damaged.
noun A tablespoon is a large spoon. It is larger than a dessert spoon and is used for serving food.

noun A tablespoon is a measuring unit used in recipes. It is the amount contained by a tablespoon, equivalent to 25 ml. Another word for this is tablespoonful. Add three level tablespoons of sugar and stir till dissolved.[qr

dictionary.entry:
tablet`tAbl@t
noun A tablet is a small round flat pill containing medicine. Take one tablet three times a day after meals.
noun A tablet is a flat piece of stone or metal with words carved or engraved on it. It is set up in a public place as a memorial of some person or event.

form.definition: noun Table tennis is an indoor game played by two or four people. Using small bats, the players hit a small, light ball to each other over a net that is stretched across the middle of a table. Another word for this is ping-pong.
noun Tableware is the dishes, glasses and utensils that you use to serve a meal. Maria used her very best tableware for the dinner party.
noun A tabloid is a newspaper which seeks to entertain its readers as much as to inform them. It usually includes a large number of photos and other pictures in its pages.

adjective If something is taboo, it is strictly forbidden because of custom or religion. Alcohol is taboo in the Muslim religion. ... WORD FAMILY noun taboo There was a strict taboo on women visiting the sacred site.
verb If you tabulate information, you arrange it in the form of a table or graph. Once the figures were tabulated, the trends became clearer to see.
adjective If something is tacit, it is understood between people without being explicitly stated. We had a tacit agreement not to oppose each other's candidates.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb tacitly

form.definition: adjective If someone is taciturn, they do not say very much and can seem unfriendly. It's difficult to work for such a taciturn bossyou never know what's wanted. You're very taciturn tonightis something the matter?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun taciturnity

form.definition: noun A tack is a short nail with a large flat head. What we need are some tacks to put up the poster.
verb When a boat tacks, it sails diagonally first in one direction and then in the other in order to move forward against the wind.
verb If you tack when you are sewing, you use large loose stitches to hold pieces of cloth together before sewing them properly.
tack on If you tack something on, you add it on without having planned it originally. You can see that the garage has been tacked on after the house was built.
verb If you tackle a problem or piece of work, you deal with it. It's time to tackle the bathroomit's needed painting for ages.
verb In sports such as football and hockey, when you tackle your opponent, you try to get the ball from them.

verb In informal language, if you say you tackle someone about something, you mean that you speak to them frankly about something you are not happy with and try to get it changed. The supervisor tackled her about being late for work so often.
noun Tackle is the equipment you use for an activity such as fishing or sailing.
noun Tackle is a set of ropes and pulleys used to lift or lower heavy materials.
adjective In informal language, if you say something is tacky, you mean that it is in bad taste. We've rented a cheap flatit's full of tacky furniture.
adjective Tacky also means slightly sticky. Be careful walking across the floorthe varnish may still be tacky in places.

dictionary.entry: tacttAkt noun Tact is skill in dealing with difficult personal situations and saying the right things so as not to upset people. He handled the matter with great tact. ... WORD FAMILY adjective tactful I decided it would be tactful to leave.adjective tactless It was pretty tactless to mention her ex-husband like that.

form.definition: noun A tactic is a means you have worked out for getting what you want. The best tactic is to wait until he's in a good mood.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective tactical This was a tactical move to lull her into a false sense of security.

form.definition: noun Tactics are a plan of action, such as a commander of troops might use to win a battle. Tactics may form part of a longer-term strategy. We were losing heavily, so we decided to change tactics in the second half of the match.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun tactician Bernard's a brilliant tacticianhe'd do well in politics.

form.definition: abbreviation for Technical and Further Education.

noun A tag is a small label attached to something and with some sort of information written on it. Make sure you put a name tag on your suitcase. The prices are individually marked on the tags. There should be a tag to show the composition of the fabric.
noun A tag is a phrase that you add at the end of a statement to form a question. If the statement is positive, the tag is negative (he's ; if the statement is negative, the tag .

tag along If you tag along, you accompany someone when they go somewhere, often because you have nothing else to do. We'll show you the wayjust tag along with us. Can't we ever go out on our own without your little brother tagging along?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb tag The birds are caught and tagged so that they can be identified later.

form.definition: noun The tail of an animal, bird or fish is the part at the end of its body, which it can usually move. The monkey swung in the tree by its tail. The dog wagged its tail with delight.
noun A tail is also a part of something at the end or rear. Our seats were in the tail of the plane. He tucked his shirt tail into his trousers.
verb If you tail someone, you follow them to see where they go and what they do. The police had been tailing the suspect for days.
tail end The tail end of something is the last part. I only heard the tail end of the news. Our float was at the tail end of the parade.
tails (a) Tails are a suit with a long-tailed coat worn by men on very formal occasions. The invitation specified white tie and tails. We hired four sets of tails for the groomsmen.
(b) Tails is the side of a coin which doesn't have a picture of a person's head on it. 'Heads or tails?' 'Tails.' 'No, it's headsI get first go.'
noun A tailor is someone who makes clothes, especially for men. Someone who makes clothes for women is usually called a dressmaker.
verb If you tailor something to suit someone, you adapt it to fulfil their exact requirements. We offer a variety of home loans tailored to your needs.
noun A taipan is a very poisonous snake found in Australia.

verb If you take something, you hold it or grasp it in your hand. He took the glass and lifted it to his lips. She took the child by the hand and led her away. Could you take this parcel while I open the door?
verb If you take something, you accept it. He refused to take any money for his trouble. Do you take credit cards? I decided to take the job. I'm sorry, this seat is taken.

verb If you take something somewhere, you carry or transport it away from the place where you usually are. The opposite of this is bring. I took my suit to the drycleaners. Don't forget to take your keys with you. It's usual to take a bottle of wine if you're invited to dinner.

verb If you take someone somewhere, you go with them and you are in charge in some way: either they are too young or old to manage on their own, or you provide the transport, or you pay the expenses. We took the children to the zoo. I'll take you into town and show you around.
verb If you take something from someone, you remove it without their permission. I can't find my penwho's taken it? The thieves took our TV and stereo.

verb You can use the word take with various nouns to show that someone is performing an action. I took a bite of the apple. He took a deep breath and began. I take a shower every morning. We took lots of photos on our holidays.
verb If something takes a certain length of time, that is the amount of time that is needed for it. The journey takes about two hours. This recipe only takes 20 minutes to prepare.
verb If a container takes a certain quantity of something, that is the amount that it is able to hold. This hall can take up to 500 people.
verb If you take a means of transport, you use it to travel. If I miss the bus I'll take a taxi. She took the next flight out of the country.
verb If you take a road or route, you travel along it. You can save time by taking the freeway. Take the next turning on the left and you'll come to the church.

verb If you take something in a particular manner, that is the attitude you have towards it. She takes her work seriously. Don't take his comments personally. She really took it hard when he left her.
verb In arithmetic, if you take one number from another, you subtract it. What do you get when you take five from thirteen?

verb In informal language, if you say you take something, you mean that you put up with it or endure it. I can't take the heat in summer. The pain will get worsecan you take it? The new teacher wouldn't take any nonsense from the class.
verb If you take someone's temperature or blood pressure, you measure it.
verb If you take medicine, you use it. The doctor prescribed some tablets for me to take. She suspected that he was taking drugs.
verb If you take a certain size in clothes or shoes, that is the size that fits you.
verb If a teacher takes a class, they teach it. Who takes you for history?
verb If a student takes a subject, they study it.
verb If troops take an area, they capture it and are able to control it. The city was taken by enemy troops.
noun In informal language, a take is a cheat or a swindle. He was the victim of a take.
noun In making films and TV shows, a take is a scene or part of a scene shot without a break. ...scene 5, take 1. He needed three takes to get it right.
take after If you take after someone you are related to, you are like them in your appearance or your character. Simon wasn't at all like his parents but took after his grandfather.

take back (a) If you take something back, you return it to the place where it came from. I must take back the video I borrowed. (b) If you take something back to the shop where you bought it, you return it because it is faulty or not suitable. If the trousers don't fit you can take them back and get the right size.
(c) If you take back something you've said, you admit that you were wrong and you apologise. I'm sorry for what I saidI take it all back. I won't forgive him till he takes back what he said.
take down If you take down what someone says, you record it in writing. The secretary took down the minutes of the meeting.

take for a ride In informal language, if you say someone takes you for a ride, you mean that they trick or deceive you. That property he bought isn't worth the money he paidhe's been taken for a ride.

take for granted (a) If you take someone for granted, you don't show proper appreciation or gratitude for them or what they've done. She was upset that her efforts were taken for granted. (b) If you take something for granted, you have no doubt that it will happen. I took it for granted that the meeting would be held at the usual place.
take in (a) If you take something in, you understand it. I was too tired to take in the finer points of the lecture.
(b) If you take in a garment, you make it smaller so that it fits better. If you take in the side seams it will fit you perfectly.
(c) If someone takes you in, they manage to trick or deceive you. Don't be taken in by colourful advertisements, look at what they actually offer you.
take it out of If something takes it out of you, it makes you exhausted. Working in the garden all day has really taken it out of me.
29 take it out on If you take it out on someone, you are nasty to them because you are in a bad mood. I know you've got problems at work, but it's not fair to take it out on me.
30 take off (a) When a plane takes off, it leaves the ground and begins its flight. We took off half an hour late, but we made up the time during the flight.
(b) If someone takes off, they leave suddenly or unexpectedly. He rushed out of the door and took off in his car without waving goodbye.
(c) If something takes off, it becomes very popular and successful. Wind surfing has really taken off as a sport in Australia.
(d) If you take off your clothes or something you are wearing, you remove them. The opposite of this is put on. Take off those muddy shoes before you go into the house.
(e) If you take someone off, you imitate them. The comedian was very funny taking off the Prime Minister.
(f) If you take time off, you do not work for a certain period. She took the morning off to go to a funeral. You've been working so hard, you deserve to take a couple of weeks off.

take out (a) If you offer to take someone out, you invite them to go with you to a restaurant or some entertainment. Usually you would pay the expenses of the outing. Let's take grandma out to dinner for her birthday. (b) If you take out insurance, you fill in a form and pay a premium so that you are covered by the insurance. We took out insurance to cover our house against theft.

take over If you take something over, you take charge of it after someone else. The director has resignedwho do you think will take over from him? They were taken over by a larger company and a lot of people were retrenched.
take part If you take part in some activity, you join in or are involved in it. We're doing a survey about cosmeticswould you like to take part?
take place If an event takes place, it happens. A street market takes place here every Sunday. When did the accident take place?
take to If you take to someone, you feel a liking for them at once. I took to Jane the first time I met her.
take up (a) If something takes up time or space, it occupies it. The children's toys were taking up too much room in the cupboard. I'm sorry to take up your time with my problems.
(b) If you take up an activity, course, or job, you begin doing it. He's taken up German at TAFE this year. My friend left the firm to take up a new job.
take up on If you take someone up on an offer, you accept their offer. He promised to give me a hand with the paintingI think I'll take him up on it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See takeoff.

form.definition: noun A takeaway is a meal that you buy in a shop and then eat on the street or in your own home.
noun A takeaway is also the shop where you buy those meals. He didn't feel like cooking, so he sent the boys off to the hamburger takeaway.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective takeaway Let's have takeaway fish and chips tonight.

form.definition: noun When you travel by plane, take-off is the beginning of the flight, when you leave the ground and begin to rise in the air. The opposite of this is landing.
noun Takings are the money that a shop or business receives from its customers. The takings are always low on a Monday.
noun Talcum powder is a fine, scented powder that you can put on your body after a bath or shower.
form.note: ... NOTE that in informal language this is often shortened to talc.

form.definition: noun A tale is a story about real or imaginary events. Jenny entertained us all with tales of her travels.
noun Talent is a natural ability to do something well. Rosa has a talent for learning languages. His musical talent was spotted at an early age, and he was encouraged to develop it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective talented His father is a talented artist. You're really talented at design.

form.definition: verb When you talk, you say things. I could hear them talking in the next room. I really miss having someone to talk to in my own language. It can help to talk about your problems with a friend.
noun Talk is conversation or discussion. It was nice meeting youI've really enjoyed our talk. There's been a lot of talk about the new project, but nothing's happened yet.
noun A talk is a speech by one person, intended to provide information. The new manager gave a talk outlining the proposals.
noun Talks are formal discussions or negotiations. Union leaders are having talks with employer groups.

talk back If you talk back to someone such as your boss, you are rude to them when they ask you to do something or they criticise you. Kaeko got the sack from her job as a graphic artist because she talked back to her boss.
talk into If you talk someone into doing something, you persuade them to do it. Mario talked me into lending him my car.
talk out of If you talk someone out of doing something, you persuade them not to do it. Dora talked me out of trying to drive all the way without a break.

talk over If you talk something over with someone, you speak to them about it in order to help you make a decision. You discuss it. You should talk it over with your family before you rush into borrowing money.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective talkative There's no peace when she's aroundshe's so talkative.

form.definition: noun Talkback is a type of radio program where members of the public take part in the broadcast by speaking to the host on the telephone.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective talkback ...talkback radio.

form.definition: adjective If a person or a building is tall, it is higher than most other ones. Charles is tall for his age. Modern cities are full of tall buildings.
adjective You also use tall when you want to say that someone is a specific height. Dario's 165 cm tall.
form.note: ... NOTE that you do not use high to describe people.

form.definition: noun A tally is a number or amount that you get by adding a lot of things together. Are you keeping a tally of what we're spending? A tally of 18 votes is needed for the motion to be passed.
verb If you tally things, you count them. The judges were tallying the final scores.
verb If two amounts or statements tally, they agree with each other. These figures don't tallyyou'd better check them again.
noun A talon is the claw of a bird of prey such as an eagle or a hawk.
adjective If an animal or a bird is tame, it is used to people and is not afraid of them. The ducks in the park are so tame they'll eat out of your hand.
adjective If something is tame, it isn't very exciting. We stopped watching the thriller as it was rather tame.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb tame We tried to tame the baby wallaby but it went bush.

form.definition: verb If you tamper with something, you change it or damage it in some way although you don't have any right to touch it. You interfere with it. Someone's been tampering with the lock on the car door and it's broken.
noun A tampon is an absorbent plug that women can wear in their vagina when they have a period, to soak up the menstrual blood.
verb When you tan, your skin becomes brown from the rays of the sun. Miguel tans easilyhe's got olive skin.
adjective Tan is a yellowish-brown colour.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun tan Don't try to get a tan too fast.adjective tan I bought a pair of tan shoes to match my handbag.adjective tanned His face was very tanned and lined.

form.definition: noun A tandem is a bicycle that two people can ride, one behind the other.
in tandem If two things happen in tandem, they happen together and are linked in some way. We are undertaking a program of health education in tandem with the offer of free testing.
noun A tang is a strong, sharp flavour or smell. I like this sauceit's got a pleasant tang to it. We could smell the tang of the sea.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective tangy Try some of this dipit's really tangy.

form.definition: noun In geometry, a tangent is a straight line which touches a curve at a single point, but doesn't cut across it.

fly off at a tangent If someone flies off at a tangent, they suddenly change their line of thought and say something that isn't connected with what they were talking about before. It's hard to discuss anything with himhe keeps flying off at a tangent.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective tangential

form.definition: noun A tangerine is a sweet fruit like a small orange.
noun Tangerine is a bright orange colour.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective tangerine The bridesmaids were dressed in tangerine silk.

form.definition: adjective If something is tangible, it can be touched and felt. It has a physical existence. She likes to invest in tangible things like antiques rather than stocks and shares.
adjective If something is tangible, it is real and certain. It is not vague or imaginary. Have you any tangible evidence of your allegations?
noun A tangle is a muddle of threads or strands which have become twisted together. It was difficult combing the tangles out of the child's hair.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb tangle Who's tangled my knitting wool?[qr

dictionary.entry:
tanktANk
noun A tank is a large container for holding liquid or gas. My petrol tank is nearly empty. She used all the hot water in the tank. The parts are dipped in a tank of special chemicals.
noun A tank is a heavily armoured military vehicle which moves on rotating metal belts and is equipped with a large gun.

form.definition: noun A tankard is a large metal mug with a handle and sometimes a lid. You use it to drink beer out of.
noun A tanker is a truck, ship or train that carries large quantities of liquid such as oil or petrol.

verb If someone or something tantalises you, they make you feel frustrated because they cause you to think about something that you want but cannot have. My cousins would tantalise me with tales of wonderful trips they knew I couldn't afford.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING of this word is tantalize. ... WORD FAMILY adjective tantalising A tantalising smell came from the kitchen.

form.definition: adjective If something is tantamount to something else, it is the same thing in effect. Her silence on the subject is tantamount to an admission of guilt.
noun A tantrum is a childish outburst of temper or anger. Jeanie throws a tantrum whenever she doesn't get her own way.[qr
noun A tap is a device which controls the flow of liquid from a pipe. Who left the tap dripping in the bathroom?

verb If you tap something, you hit it lightly. I tapped the wall to see if it was solid. He tapped her on the shoulder and whispered something. Manuel was tapping his foot on the floor to the beat of the music.
verb If you tap a resource, you make use of some of it. Australia still has immense mineral reserves to be tapped. Why not tap into the services that the library offers?
verb If someone taps a telephone line, they attach a special connection to it so that they can secretly listen to the calls. George wouldn't talk to me on the phone because he thinks it's tapped.
on tap If something is on tap, it is easily available. My aunt works for a solicitor, so we've got legal advice on tap.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun tap She gave him a tap on the shoulder.

form.definition: noun A tape is a storage medium for sound, video or computer information. At the ABC shop I bought a CD and two tapes. We rewound the tape to watch the last half hour again. The data is backed up onto tape overnight.

noun Tape is also a long thin strip of paper, cloth or other material. The parcel was tied with pink tape. I covered the seams with tape to stop them fraying. Have you got some glue or sticky tape I could borrow?
tape deck A tape deck is a machine on which you can play cassette tapes. You can also use it to record music or other sounds onto tapes.
tape measure A tape measure is a long strip of cloth or flexible steel marked with centimetres and millimetres which is used for measuring things.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb tape I taped the CD Nick lent me.

form.definition: verb If something tapers, it gradually becomes thinner or narrower at one end. The church tower is broad at the base and tapers to a tall steeple.
noun A taper is a long thin candle. I used a taper to light the wood in the stove.

dictionary.entry: tape-recorder`tEIp-r@k@:d@ noun A tape-recorder is a machine which records sounds on magnetic tape and can play them back. ... WORD FAMILY verb tape-record All the interviews were tape-recorded for later analysis.noun tape-recording A tape-recording of the conversation was played to the court.

form.definition: noun A tapestry is a piece of heavy cloth with a design or picture woven into it.
noun Tar is a thick, black, sticky substance used for making the surface of roads. It goes hard when it cools.
noun Tar is any thick, sticky substance that comes from an organic source. These cigarettes are relatively low in tar.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb tar The traffic delays were caused by workmen tarring the road.

form.definition: noun A target is an object or place that you aim to hit. Carl's arrow landed in the centre of the target. The bridge was the enemy's main target.
noun A target is something that you aim to reach or achieve. It is a goal. The club's target was to raise $2000 at the fete. The sales figures were on target.
noun A target can also be someone who is the victim of something unpleasant that is directed at them. They made Bill the target of their mockery.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb target Our training program targets the long-term unemployed.

form.definition: noun A tariff is a government levy or tax on goods which are brought into a country.
noun The tariff is also the price or list of prices that a hotel charges for rooms and meals. The tariff here is too high so we're moving to another hotel.
noun Tarmac is a mixture of tar and gravel which is used for making the surface of roads.
noun A tarmac is also any area which has this mixture on its surface, such as a runway at an airport.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective tarmac

form.definition: verb When metal tarnishes, it becomes dull and stained. The silver teapot had tarnished badly and needed polishing. Stainless steel does not tarnish.
verb If something tarnishes someone's reputation, it makes them seem less honourable. The scandal over the missing funds severely tarnished her reputation.
noun A tarpaulin is a large heavy piece of canvas that has been made waterproof and is used as protection from rain. We set up a tarpaulin in the backyard for the party in case it rained.
noun Tarragon is a herb used to give flavour in cooking and salads.
noun A tart is an open pie filled with fruit or jam.
adjective If something is tart, it is sour in taste. Don't buy any more of those tart apples.
adjective If a remark is tart, it is sharp or unkind. Something he said annoyed her and she gave a tart reply.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb tartly noun tartness

form.definition: noun Tartan is a fabric design which has irregular checks and stripes in dull colours such as blue, green, black and red. These patterns are traditionally associated with Scotland.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective tartan ...a tartan tie.

form.definition: abbreviation for Tasmania.
noun A task is work that has to be done. It is often a small job that you don't like doing, such as washing up or cleaning. My task for the day is to clean the car.
task force A task force is a team of people who are given the job of performing a specific task for a certain period of time.
take to task If you take someone to task, you tell them that you are displeased about something they have done. The lecturer really took us to task for arriving late.
noun A tassel is a bunch of threads hanging from a round head at the end of a cord. Tassels are often attached as decorations to curtains, flags and clothes.
noun Taste is the sense with which you experience flavour when you put food or drink into your mouth. I've got a cold, so I've lost my sense of taste.
noun The taste of a food or drink is its flavour which makes it different from other foods. This coffee has a bitter taste. I love the taste of mangoes.

noun A taste of a certain food or dish is a small amount of it that you eat for the sake of experiencing its flavour. May I have a taste of your chicken? 'Would you like some of the cheesecake?' 'Just a taste, please.'
noun If you have a taste for something, you have a liking for it. You enjoy it. He has a taste for fast cars. I've developed a taste for classical music.

noun If someone has taste or good taste, they have a sense of what is attractive and appropriate. If they have bad taste, they often choose things that other people think are ugly or unsuitable. She has very good taste in clothesshe always looks great. Their house is decorated in the most appalling taste. It was a lapse of taste to mention her operation over the meal.

verb If you taste food or drink, you eat or drink a small amount of it in order totest its flavour. I'd like to taste this cheese before I buy some. Taste this sauce for me, will you? Do you think it needs more chilli?
verb If food or drink tastes of something, it has a certain flavour. This meat dish tastes of garlic. What do fresh dates taste like? This soup tastes horrible. The milk tasted as if it had gone off.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See tasteful.adjective See tasteless.adjective See tasty.

form.definition: adjective If something is tasteful, it is attractive and has style. It is in good taste. The bride's mother wore a tasteful blue suit with a matching hat.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb tastefully The flat was tastefully decorated.

form.definition: adjective If food is tasteless, it has no flavour. The vegetables had been overcooked and were quite tasteless.
adjective If something is tasteless, it is unattractive and vulgar. It is in bad taste. Her outfit was spoilt by tasteless plastic jewellery. He made several tasteless jokes about diseases.

dictionary.entry: tasty`tEIsti:tastiertastiest adjective If food is tasty, it is pleasant to eat and full of flavour. It is appetising. She knows how to cook a tasty meal. The beef stew was very tasty.

form.definition: adjective If something is tattered, it has tears and rips in it because it has been used so much. She had only a thin and tattered coat to protect her from the cold. The jacket of this book has become very tattered.
If clothes are in tatters, they are ragged and torn. What have you been doing, Jamie? Your shirt is in tatters.

noun A tattoo is a picture or writing on someone's body which it is impossible to remove. It is made by injecting coloured ink under the surface of the skin. Emilio had a tattoo of a mermaid on his arm.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb tattoo (tattoos, tattoed, tattoing) His arms were tattoed with mermaids.

dictionary.entry: tatty`tAti:tattiertattiest adjective If something is tatty, it is in a poor state of repair. He should smarten himself up and get rid of that tatty old suit. The room was full of tatty furniture.

form.definition: verb Taught is the past tense and past participle of teach.
verb If someone taunts you, they tease you and say things they know will make you upset and angry. Gian's always taunting his sister about her lisp.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun taunt I tried to ignore the jeers and taunts of the crowd.

form.definition: adjective If something is taut, it is stretched tight. The wire between the fence posts was pulled taut. His taut muscles needed relaxing.

dictionary.entry: tautologyt@:`tOl@dZi:tautologies noun A tautology is a fault of style where you repeat the same idea in different words, without adding to the meaning. An example is We don't need any unnecessary items. ... WORD FAMILY adjective tautological

form.definition: noun A tavern is a place where food and alcoholic drinks are served.
adjective If something is tawdry, it is vulgar and made of cheap, poor quality materials. She wore a tawdry glittering dress to the reception.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun tawdriness

dictionary.entry: tawny`t@:ni:tawniertawniest adjective If something is tawny, it is yellowish-brown in colour. The animal had a tawny coat.

form.definition: noun Tax is the money that you have to pay to the government to meet the cost of things such as education and the armed forces. No government wants to increase taxes just before an election.
verb When a government taxes something, it charges a tax on it. Luxury goods are usually heavily taxed.
verb If something taxes you, it imposes a strain or burden on you. The stress of her job has taxed her health. The children's constant demands were beginning to tax my patience.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective taxable You can claim various deductions to reduce your taxable income.noun taxation The burden of taxation is particularly heavy on lower income groups.adjective taxing I found the constant travel involved in my job very taxing.

form.definition: noun A taxi is a car with a driver which you hire to take you where you want to go. He caught a taxi home from the station.
verb When an aircraft taxies, it moves along the runway before taking off, or after landing. The plane had landed and was taxiing to the terminal.
taxi rank A taxi rank is a place in the street where taxis wait to be hired.
noun Tea is the dried and prepared leaves of a shrub. I like Ceylon teas.
noun Tea is the drink made by pouring boiling water onto these leaves. Would you like a cup of tea?
noun Tea can refer to the meal people have in the late afternoon or early evening. We usually have our tea at seven o'clock.
cup of tea If you say something is your cup of tea, you mean that you particularly like it. Jazz music isn't really my cup of tea. For exercise, swimming's more my cup of tea than running.

noun A teabag is a small bag made of a thin material containing dry tea. You put it in a teapot or cup and add hot water to make a drink of tea. The flavour from the leaves comes out into the water while they remain inside the bag.

verb If you teach someone to do something, you show or tell them how to do it and help them until they are able to do it well. My brother taught me to swim. Bruce was teaching me how to use the computer.
verb If someone teaches, they work as a teacher. He teaches at the local high school. She teaches English to migrants.
noun A teacher is someone whose job is to help students to learn, for example at a school or college. She's a popular teacher with her students. Caitlin wants to be a teacher when she grows up.
noun A teacher's aide is someone employed to help a teacher in the classroom by doing tasks which take up time but which can be done by a person who is not qualified as a teacher.
noun A team is a group of people, each with a different role, who work together to perform a task. They had to call in a team of experts to solve their problem.
noun A team is a group of players that play on the same side in sport. Which team will you barrack for?
team up If you team up with someone, you join with them to do something together. Anna teamed up with Nicky to travel around Sicily.
noun A teapot is a jug that you use for making and serving tea. It is made of pottery or metal and usually has a round shape with a spout, handle and lid.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See pot.

dictionary.entry:
teartI@ for senses 1 and 5; for senses 2, 3, 4, 6 and tE@tearstoretorntearing
noun A tear is a drop of liquid that comes from your eye, especially when you weep. Tears were streaming down her face as she said goodbye.
noun A tear in something such as cloth or paper is a place where it has come apart under strain. My new shirt has a tear under the arm.
verb If you tear something such as cloth or paper, you make it come apart or you damage it by putting a rip in it. Tear the paper in half. She tore up the note and threw it away. I tore the page out of my notebook. He tore his shirt on a branch in the bush.
verb In informal language, if you say you tear somewhere, you mean that you go there in a hurry. I haven't time to talk nowI'm tearing off to a meeting. The car tore up to the house and screeched to a halt.
in tears If someone is in tears, they are weeping. Emily was in tears because she had failed her exams. He broke down in tears and was unable to continue.
6 tear away If you tear someone away from something, you force them to leave it. Stan has to be torn away from the computer to eat and sleep. I loved watching the dolphinsI could hardly tear myself away.
tear into If you tear into someone, you speak to them angrily or criticise them harshly. She didn't like what he said and she tore into him.
... BE CAREFUL with the pronunciation of this word: the first meaning and the phrase in tears are pronounced differently from the rest of the meanings.

form.definition: verb If someone teases you, they make fun of you or annoy you in what is supposed to be a playful way. Her friends teased her about her foreign accent. My brother used to tease me by pulling my hair.

tease out If you tease something out, you separate the parts that have become tightly knotted together. She washed the dog and patiently teased out its matted coat. ... WORD FAMILY noun tease Don't take any noticeJan's a terrible tease.
noun A teaspoon is a small spoon used to stir tea or coffee.
noun A teaspoon is also the amount of food or liquid that a spoon of this size holds. Another word for this is teaspoonful. I take two teaspoons of sugar in my tea.
noun A teat is the rubber top on a baby's bottle.
noun A teat is also the nipple through which a female mammal feeds milk to its young.
noun A tea towel is a cloth for drying dishes and kitchen utensils after you have washed them up.
noun In informal language, tech is short for technical college.

adjective Technical means to do with the knowledge involved in a particular subject. She didn't have the technical knowledge to explain how it works. 'Hypertension' is a technical term doctors use for high blood pressure.
adjective Technical also means relating to the details of how something works. Technical issues have still to be resolved before the project can go ahead.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb technically Technically, I didn't qualify for the scheme, but they stretched a point.noun technicality (technicalities) I engaged a solicitor to deal with all the technicalities.

form.definition: A technical college is an educational institution where people who have left school can study practical subjects. She's studying computer graphics at technical college.
noun A technician is someone whose job is to maintain apparatus or machinery. The photocopier's playing up againwe'd better call the technician. Adnan works as a technician at the power plant.
noun A technique is a particular way or method of doing something. The techniques of sound recording improve every year.
noun Technique is also practical skill. He is a pianist with a brilliant technique.
noun Technology is the practical use of science in industry. ... WORD FAMILY noun technological
noun A teddy bear or a teddy is a soft toy bear.

adjective If something is tedious, it is boring and makes you irritated or depressed. I hope you have the patience for this tedious task. I found it tedious to repeat the same details to each new arrival.
noun In golf, a tee is the starting place for each hole played.
noun A tee is also the small holder from which you drive the ball at the start of each hole.
tee off When you tee off, you begin playing a round of golf. What time do you tee off in the competition tomorrow?
tee up If you tee something up, you organise it or get it ready. Everything has been teed up for our outing.
verb If you say it is teeming, you mean that it is raining heavily. It teemed all day yesterday. It was teeming down when I left home.
teem with If a place teems with something, it is full of it so that it seems very busy and lively. This forest once teemed with birdlife.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective teeming I ventured into the teeming rain. The mall is always teeming on Saturdays.

form.definition: noun A teenager is someone who is between thirteen and nineteen years old.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective teenage She has two teenage daughters.

form.definition: noun A person's teens are the time when they are between thirteen and nineteen years old. I was very fat in my teens. Her youngest must be in the early teens by now.
noun Teeth is the plural form of tooth.
adjective If someone is teetotal, they do not drink alcohol at all.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun teetotaller I've been a teetotaller for seven years now.

form.definition: noun A telecast is a broadcast by television, often on a closed circuit system. There'll be a live telecast of the opera in the stadium.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb telecast

dictionary.entry: telecommunicationstEl@k@mju:n@`kEIS@ns noun Telecommunications is the process of sending and receiving messages by telephone, radio or satellite.

form.definition: noun Telepathy is the sharing of thoughts between people without communicating by the normal use of the senses. How did you guess I wanted to see you? It must have been telepathy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective telepathic

form.definition: noun A telephone is the apparatus that you use to talk to people who are not in the same place as you. I've got a combined telephone and answering machine. The telephone is ringing.
noun The telephone is the electrical system by which this happens. Before the telephone, country people were very isolated.
verb If you telephone someone, you dial their number and then speak to them when they answer. She promised to telephone if she was delayed.
4 on the telephone (a) If you are on the telephone, you are talking to someone by telephone. I can't answer the door, I'm on the telephone.
(b) If you are on the telephone, you have a telephone where people can contact you. We'll let you know when it's ready. Are you on the telephone?
form.note: ... NOTE that you can use the more informal short form phone in each of these meanings. ... WORD FAMILY adjective telephone ...a telephone number.

dictionary.entry: telephone exchange`tEl@f@Un Eks`tSEIndZ noun A telephone exchange is a building where electrical connections are made between telephone lines, so that people can make and receive calls.

form.definition: noun A telescope is a tube-shaped instrument which makes objects that are far away look closer and larger. With his telescope he was able to read the ship's name.
verb If something telescopes, its sections fold away into each other. The first and second carriages telescoped in the impact of the train crash.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective telescopic The hunters had guns with telescopic sights.

form.definition: noun A television or television set is a box-like apparatus with a screen which picks up broadcast sound and pictures. We've replaced our old television with a small portable.

noun Television is the medium by which people receive sounds and pictures on their television sets. Chris used to work in radio, but now he's in television. I didn't feel like going out, so I stayed in and watched television.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this in informal language is TV. ... WORD FAMILY verb televise The interview with the Prime Minister will be televised live.adjective television ...a television program.

form.definition: verb If you tell someone something, you give them some information. She told me that she was getting married soon. Can you tell me how much it will cost to repair this watch? Tell me if I'm hurting you. Nobody told me the date of the meeting.
verb If you tell a lie, a story or a joke, you say it. What made you tell those dreadful jokes? He's good at telling stories to children.
verb If you tell someone to do something, you order them to do it. I told them not to run in the corridor. When will they learn to do as they're told?
verb If you can tell something, you recognise it or know about it. You're unhappyI can tell. I've corrected the mistake and you can't tell where it was.
tell on If you tell on someone, you reveal something that they have done wrong to someone in authority. You dob them in. If I help you, will you promise not to tell on me?
tell off In informal language, if you say you tell someone off, you mean that you scold them for doing something wrong. They were told off for always being late.
noun A teller is someone whose job is to receive and pay out money in a bank.
noun Your temper is the mood or state of mind that you are in. Ross was in a very good temper after winning at golf.
noun If someone has a temper, they are inclined to have outbursts of anger. You'd better be careful how you tell himhe's got a shocking temper.
in a temper If you are in a temper or in a bad temper, you are feeling irritable and angry. She stormed out of the room in a temper.
lose your temper If you lose your temper, you suddenly show anger. When the TV wouldn't work, Harold lost his temper and started banging it with his fists.
noun Your temperament is your personality or character. Sally made friends quickly because of her easygoing temperament.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See temperamental.

form.definition: adjective If someone is temperamental, they are difficult to deal with because they are very emotional and their moods change a lot.
adjective If you say a piece of equipment is temperamental, you mean that it often doesn't work very well.
adjective Temperamental also means relating to people's temperaments or personalities. Despite our temperamental differences, we get on extremely well.
noun The temperature of something is the measure of how hot or cold it is. 'What's the temperature today?' 'It's about 20 degrees.'

noun If you have a temperature, you have a fever. The temperature of your body is higher than normal. Anna placed her hand on her daughter's forehead to see if she had a temperature. The child was running a temperature of 40 degrees.
adjective If something is temporary, it is intended to last for a short time only. This is just a temporary arrangement till the renovations are finished.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is permanent. ... WORD FAMILY adverb temporarily This vending machine is temporarily out of order.

form.definition: verb If you tempt someone, you encourage them to do something which perhaps they really shouldn't do, by making it seem very attractive. These glossy brochures and easy terms tempt people to spend more than they can afford. Can I tempt you to another scone?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun temptation He resisted the temptation to steal.adjective tempting A rival company made him a tempting offer. That cake looks very tempting.

form.definition: noun Ten is the number 10, nine plus one.
adjective If you have ten things, the number of things you have adds up to ten.

adjective If you are tenacious, you do not give up easily. You continue with what you are doing even though it may be very difficult. Emiko is really tenaciousshe refused to give up in the marathon, even though she was trailing the field and the temperature was 30 degrees.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb tenaciously noun tenacity

form.definition: noun A tenant is someone who pays rent for the use of a house, room, office or land.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun tenancy (tenancies) We have a six month tenancy on the flat.

form.definition: verb If something tends to happen, it often happens. That is the way things generally are. Loose keys tend to get lost. It tends to get cold at night. I tend to get sick on planes.
verb If something tends in a certain direction, it moves that way as it changes. Property prices are tending downwards. Government policy is tending towards lower taxes.
verb If you tend someone or something, you look after them. He tended his sick wife caringly. She was outside tending her garden.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun tendency (tendencies) She has a tendency to be careless.

form.definition: adjective If meat is tender, it is soft and easy to chew. It is not tough. I enjoyed that tender piece of steak.
adjective If a part of your body is tender, it is painful or sore when you touch it. My foot is healing but it's still too tender to walk on.
adjective Something that is tender is gentle, kind and loving. Babies need the tender care their parents give. She's got a tender heartshe doesn't like to see animals suffering.
verb In formal language, if you say someone tenders something, you mean that they offer it. She decided to tender her resignation. PLEASE TENDER EXACT FARE
noun A tender is an offer to do a job for a certain price. The council is calling for tenders to renovate the public library.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb tenderly He held her tenderly in his arms.noun tenderness This ointment should relieve the swelling and tenderness.

form.definition: noun A tendon is a strong band of body tissue which joins muscle to a bone. He strained a tendon in his knee and won't be able to play sport for a while.

noun A tenement is an old building of several storeys, with a large number of rooms or small apartments in it occupied by different families. As soon as they could, they moved out of the crowded tenement into their own house.
noun Tennis is a game for two or four players. Each player has a racquet to hit the ball over the net which divides the court.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective tennis ...a tennis racquet. ...a tennis match.

form.definition: noun A tenor is a male singer with a high voice.
adjective If you are tense, you are suffering from mental or nervous strain. The night before the interview I was too tense to sleep. The atmosphere in court was tense as we waited for the verdict.
adjective If something is tense, it is taut or stretched tight. The muscles in your neck are very tenseyou need a good massage.
noun In grammar, the tense of a verb shows whether the action happened in the past, is happening at present, or will happen in the future.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun tension The tension mounted as we waited. I relaxed the tension on the cable.

form.definition: noun A tent is a temporary shelter made from canvas or nylon which is held up by poles and ropes. It took us ages to put up our tent the first time we went camping.
noun Tentacles are long thin flexible parts that certain animals such as octopuses and jellyfish have. They use them for feeling or grasping things.

adjective If something is tentative, it is not definite. We can only make tentative plans for the barbecue till we have a better idea about numbers. I've made a tentative booking for the 18thI have to confirm within three days.

adjective If someone is tentative, they are not bold or confident. Don't be so tentative with your suggestionswe all want to hear what you have to say. The baby took a few tentative steps, then fell over.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb tentatively I'll put you down tentatively for three tickets.

form.definition: adjective The tenth person or thing is the one which comes next in order after the ninth.
noun A tenth is one of ten equal parts of something.

adjective If something is tenuous, it is slight or vague. The evidence is too tenuous to stand up in court. There is only a tenuous family connection between usher cousin is married to my brother. ... WORD FAMILY adverb tenuously
adjective If a liquid is tepid, it is moderately warm. The water in the bath was barely tepid. They served us tepid beer and soggy chips.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is lukewarm.

form.definition: noun A term is a fixed period of time. She served three terms of office as councillor. I invested the money for a term of three months. We need a solution for the long term.
noun A term is one of the periods of time that the teaching year is divided into, in schools and colleges. There are usually four terms in Australian schools.

noun A term is a word or phrase which has a special meaning in a particular subject. The contract contained a lot of obscure legal terms. I didn't know the correct term for the thing, so I took it with me to the hardware store.
noun The terms of an agreement are the conditions in it. They were not happy with the terms of the lease.

noun You can also use terms to refer to the way something is expressed or the relationship between people. She protested in the strongest possible terms. I'm still on good terms with my ex-husband. I'm thinking in terms of weeks rather than months for the trip.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See terminology.

form.definition: adjective If an illness is terminal, it is incurable and eventually causes the death of the patient. I'm afraid his condition is terminal.
noun A terminal is a place where passengers join or leave a bus, train, ship or plane, when they begin or end a journey. The liner came in at the overseas terminal.
noun A terminal is a point where current enters or leaves in an electric circuit.
noun A computer terminal consists of a keyboard and screen which are linked to a computer. Using the keyboard you can give instructions to the computer and get information from it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb terminally She is terminally ill.

form.definition: verb In formal language, if you say something terminates, you mean that it comes to an end. If you say you terminate something, you mean that you bring it to an end. The next train terminates at Central. The minister abruptly terminated the interview. She decided to terminate the pregnancy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun termination

form.definition: noun Terminology is a set of specialised words and phrases relating to a particular subject. I'm not familiar with computer terminology.
noun A terminus is the station or stop at the end of a railway line or bus route.
noun A termite is an insect which eats dead wood.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is white ant.

form.definition: noun A terrace is one of a series of levels artificially created on a slope or hillside.
noun A terrace is an outdoor living area connected to a house. Drinks were being served on the terrace.
noun A terrace is also a row of similar houses joined together, or a house in such a row.
noun You use the word terrain when you are describing the natural features of a stretch of land. It was a difficult hike across rugged, hilly terrain.
adjective If something is described as terrestrial, it lives or grows on land or on Earth.

adjective If something is terrible, it causes people to feel shock and horror. Everyone was appalled by the terrible crime. The starving children were a terrible sight. He was crippled in a terrible accident. They sustained terrible injuries.

adjective In informal language, if you say something is terrible, you mean that it's very bad. I've got a terrible headache. That's a terrible waste of money. He's got terrible taste in clothes. This soup smells terrible. The traffic was terrible this morning.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb See terribly.

form.definition: adverb In informal language, you use terribly to emphasise adjectives and other adverbs. The instructions are terribly confusing. It can get terribly hot here in summer. I'm sure I did terribly badly in the exam. I'm not terribly happy about the situation.
adjective In informal language, if you say that something is terrific, you mean that it is very good or enjoyable. That was a terrific dinner you cooked. You look terrific in that outfit.
adjective In informal language, terrific can also mean very great or extreme. There was a terrific din as the fire alarm went off. Wet weather causes a terrific number of accidents on the roads.
verb If something terrifies you, it frightens you very much. Snakes terrify me.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective terrified I was absolutely terrified at the thought of speaking in public.adjective terrifying Getting lost in the bush was a terrifying experience.

form.definition: noun A territory is land thought of as belonging to someone. They crossed the border into German territory. You are trespassing on my territory. They won back part of the territory held by the enemy.

noun In Australia, the Northern Territory and Australian Capital Territory are officially referred to as territories instead of states. Legal requirements differ in the various states and territories.
noun Terror is great fear. She cried out in terror as the truck bore down on them.
noun In informal language, a mischievous child is sometimes called a terror. She can be a real little terror sometimes.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb See terrify.verb See terrorise.

form.definition: verb If someone terrorises you, they keep you in fear with threats of violence. Vandals were roaming the streets and terrorising the neighbourhood.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING of this word is terrorize.

form.definition: noun Terrorism is the use of violence to fight a government. The minister denounced the bomb attack as an act of terrorism.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun terrorist

form.definition: adjective A terse way of speaking is short and almost rude. His terse answer made me think he was angry.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb tersely noun terseness

form.definition: adjective Tertiary is a formal word meaning that something belongs to a third order or rank, after things that are described as primary and secondary.
tertiary education Tertiary education is the education you receive after you've finished secondary school if you go to a university or college.
noun A test is an experiment to find out whether something works properly or what it is like. The first atomic tests were carried out in secrecy. I think I need a hearing test.
noun A test is also an examination to show how much you know about something. We've got a geography test on Tuesday. To get a driver's licence you have to pass a knowledge test and a driving test.
test match In the sport of rugby or cricket, a test match is one of a series of matches played between two countries.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb test I prodded the potatoes to test whether they were cooked.

form.definition: noun A testament is a written statement saying how someone wishes their property to be distributed after their death.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is will.

form.definition: noun The Old Testament and the New Testament are the two main divisions of the Bible.
noun A man's testicles are the two round sex organs which produce sperm.
verb If you testify in a law court, you give evidence and swear or solemly state that it is true. He testified against the accused. Sally testified that she had seen the crime.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See testimony.

form.definition: noun A testimonial is a written statement about someone's character or performance in a job. Usually it is given to the person it is about, whereas a reference is often confidential.
noun A testimonial is also an expression of appreciation. The gift was a testimonial for his long and loyal service.
noun Testimony is evidence given in a law court. He was called as a witness to give testimony about what he had seen.
noun If something is a testimony to something else, it gives evidence of it. His good results are a testimony to the hard work he has put in.
noun A tether is a rope or chain by which an animal is tied to something fixed,such a post, so that it will not wander far.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb tether The horse was tethered to a tree.

form.definition: noun A text is a piece of writing. We studied a number of modern texts. Each illustration is accompanied by an explanatory text. Your essay should be around 3000 words of text, excluding notes and bibliography.
noun A texta is a thick felt pen which comes in different colours and which is used especially by children for colouring in.
noun A textbook is a book that students use as part of their course. It contains information about a subject and often questions and exercises.
noun A textile is a piece or type of cloth. He set up a business exporting furnishing textiles. The walls were draped with textiles.
noun The texture of something is how it feels to the touch, for example whether it is rough or smooth. I like the rich texture of this carpet.
noun Thai is the standard language spoken in Thailand.
adjective If someone or something comes from Thailand, you describe them as Thai.
conjunction You use than in making comparisons. Jan is taller than I am. He is richer than I will ever be. I feel better than I did yesterday. It's later than I thought.
preposition You use than in making comparisons. Jan is taller than me. I can't come sooner than Friday.
preposition You also use than in phrases expressing a choice or alternative. I'd rather come with you than wait here. Have you any other ones than these?

verb When you thank someone, you express your gratitude to them. He thanked me for driving him home. It is polite to thank your host before leaving. This is just a small gift to thank you for everything you've done.

thank goodness or thank heavens You can say thank goodness or thank heavens to show that you are very pleased or relieved about something. Thank goodness you're safe! Marcia was at home, thank heavensI don't know what I'd have done otherwise.

thanks Thanks is a slightly more informal expression than thank you. You can emphasise it by saying thanks very much or thanks a lot. Thanks very much for the warning. 'How is your sore arm?' 'Much better, thanks.'

thanks to If you say that something happens thanks to someone or something, you mean that it's because of them that it happens. The project went smoothly thanks to her expert advice. Thanks to you the whole thing is ruined!
thank you Thank you is the usual thing you say when someone has done something for you or given you something. You can emphasise it by saying thank you very much.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective thankful I was really thankful to Greta for her help. I'm just thankful he's alive.

form.definition: determiner You use that to show which person or thing you mean. That girl is my daughter.
determiner You use that to refer to the person or thing which is further away in place or time. I would like that one over there, not this one. Remember those happy evenings we used to enjoy?
pronoun You can use that to refer to a person or thing which has already been indicated. That is my son in the photo. Are those the ones I chose?
pronoun That is used as a subject or object of a relative clause. Where is the new shirt that I bought? Who was the person that rang earlier?

conjunction That is used to introduce a noun clause. Note that that may often be omitted in this type of clause. I think that the time has come for us to leave. Does it say that you cannot smoke here?
adverb In informal language, that is used in demonstrating an amount or quantity. The snake was about that long. He's not that good, you know.

7 and all that In informal to stand for all the other things left unsaid. She stayed home to do the washing and vacuum the house and all that. 8 that's that You use that's that to mean that a matter has been closed or finished and you cannot do or say anything more. He wouldn't change his mind, so that's that.
noun Thatch is material such as dried straw, reeds or leaves used to cover a roof.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb thatch ...to thatch a roof.

form.definition: verb When something thaws, it melts or it becomes soft because the water in it melts. The ice will begin to thaw as soon as the weather gets warmer. The meat will have to be thawed before you cook it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun thaw The streets are very muddy during the spring thaw.

form.definition: determiner You use the before nouns or noun groups to refer to something specific. It's the house with two chimneys. Ask the tall boy to sit down.
determiner You use the before a singular noun to make a general statement. The eagle is a bird of prey. The car is causing pollution in cities.
determiner You can use the before an adjective or participle to make it into a noun. I cannot do the impossible. The wounded were taken to hospital.
determiner You use the with a superlative to mean the greatest degree of anything. This is the highest mountain I've ever climbed. The quickest way to get there is by road.
determiner You can use the with a surname to refer to a family or couple. The Newmans have arrived.
determiner You can use the to emphasise the importance of someone or something. Note that in this use, the is emphasised. Was that the Patrick White? It's the place to go.
noun A theatre is a building where plays, operas or ballets are performed. The college is right next to a disused theatre.
noun The theatre means the world of live performances on stage. She hopes to make a career in the theatre. I haven't been to the theatre for ages. My interests include films and theatre.

noun A theatre or operating theatre is the room in a hospital where surgical operations are performed. She was rushed to the theatre for an emergency caesarian. Everything used in the theatre must be absolutely sterile.
noun A theatre or lecture theatre is a large room with tiers of seats in which lectures are given. Prof. Handley will be speaking in the main theatre.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective theatre ...a theatre ticket. ...a theatre company.

form.definition: adjective Theatrical is a rather formal word meaning relating to the theatre. She has starred in a number of theatrical productions, as well as in the cinema. Felix is studying theatrical design.

adjective If something is theatrical, it is deliberately dramatic or showy. All conversation stopped as she made a theatrical exit. Why does he have to be so theatrical about everything? The room is incredibly theatrical, with huge carvings on the walls.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb theatrically She sighed theatrically.

form.definition: noun Theft is the crime of stealing. He was charged with theft. Many thefts have been reported in this street.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See thief.

form.definition: pronoun Their is a possessive form of they, used before a noun. They clapped their hands. All of their relatives are dead.
pronoun In informal language, you can use their to mean 'his or her'. Who's left their umbrella behind?
pronoun Theirs is a possessive form of them, used without a noun following. Our car is much older than theirs. They claimed the land was theirs.
pronoun In informal language, you can use theirs to mean 'his or hers'. There's an umbrella herehas anyone left theirs behind?
pronoun Them is the objective form of they. I hate them all. Put them in the box. We sent them a letter. I ran past them and waved.
pronoun In informal language, you can use them to mean 'him or her'. If anyone calls, tell them I'm out.
noun The theme of something such as a speech or book is what it is about. One of the novel's themes was how attitudes have changed since the war.
pronoun Themselves is the reflexive form of they. It was obvious they were enjoying themselves. They decided to keep the decision to themselves.
pronoun Themselves is an emphatic form of they. The story is truethey admit it themselves.
pronoun In informal language, you can use themselves to mean 'himself or herself'. Sometimes the form themself is also used with this meaning. Everyone must look after themselves.
adverb Then means 'at that time'. 1980 is a long time agoI was a child then. I can't come to the next meetingI'll be away then.
adverb Then also means 'next in order of time'. I'll finish writing this letter first, and then go shopping. James travelled to America, then Canada and then on to England.
adverb Then can mean 'in that case'. If he doesn't improve, then we'll have to call a doctor. 'We really need your help.' 'All right then, I'll come over.'
noun Then can mean 'that time'. I'll be away until May, so goodbye till then.

then again If you use the phrase then again, you are about to present the other side of an argument or discussion. Another way of saying this is on the other hand. I can see the advantage of putting lots of energy into your career, but then again it's important for your health to relax occasionally.

dictionary.entry: theologyTi:`Ol@dZi: noun If you study theology, you study religion or the beliefs of a particular religion. ... WORD FAMILY noun theologian adjective theological

form.definition: noun In mathematics, a theorem is a statement which has to be proved by logical reasoning. ...Pythagoras's theorem.

noun A theory is a possible explanation of something. It is based on observation and reasoning but it is not definitely proved. My theory is that the cat knocked over the vase, but Jo thinks it was a ghost. Various theories have been advanced about her disappearance. ...Einstein's Theory of Relativity.
noun Theory is the general principles that underlie an art or science. You must first learn the theory and then put it into practice.
in theory You use in theory to refer to the way things are supposed to be, rather than the way they actually are. In theory applications closed last week, but they'll probably still let you enter.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective theoretical He's studying theoretical physics.adverb theoretically It's theoretically possible, but it's never actually been done.verb theorise (<or> theorize) Without hard evidence, we can only theorise about the cause of the smash.

form.definition: adjective If something is therapeutic, it does you good. It improves your health or makes you feel better. Doctors say that fresh air, exercise and a good diet are therapeutic. After a hard day at work, I find it very therapeutic to listen to classical music.

noun Therapy is treatment intended to cure or relieve a medical or psychological problem. He is receiving radiation therapy for his cancer. If you are in severe distress you may wish to seek counselling or therapy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See therapeutic.noun therapist

form.definition: adverb There means 'at that place', or 'to that place'. We're almost there. He went to the coffee shop and waited there for his friend.
adverb There also means 'at that point' or in connection with it. He read to the end of the page and stopped there. There I agree with you.
adverb If something is available or exists, it is there. The facilities are there for you to use. She imagines more problems than are really there.
adverb You use there to stress or draw attention to someone or something. There goes the busI've just missed it. Where's Erica? Ah, there she is!

pronoun There is used with verbs like be, seem and appear to introduce a sentence or clause. There's someone on the phone for you. There does not appear to be any evidence for this. There are too many people in this lift!
interjection There is used in exclamations to express sympathy or satisfaction. There, there, don't cry. There! I've finished at last.
adverb You use thereabouts to show that what you say is approximate. It happened at five o'clock or thereabouts. It should cost fifty dollars or thereabouts.
adverb Thereafter is a formal word meaning 'after that'. He left for the city and I never saw him again thereafter.
adverb Thereby is a formal word meaning 'by doing that'. Jon paid the registration, thereby automatically renewing his membership.

adverb You use therefore to show that something happens or is true because of something else. This car uses less petrol and is therefore cheaper to run. The road is blocked and therefore we must detour.
contraction There'll is the spoken form of there will.
adverb Thereupon is a formal word used to show that something happens immediately after something else and as a result of it. He said he was leaving and she thereupon burst into tears.
noun A thermometer is an instrument for measuring temperature.
noun A thermos is a container used to keep drinks hot or cold. Anna took a thermos of coffee to work.
noun A thermostat is a device which keeps the temperature of something such as a room, an oven or an engine at the desired level.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb thermostatically The temperature is thermostatically controlled.

dictionary.entry: thesaurusT@`s@:r@sthesauruses noun A thesaurus is a reference book which arranges the words of a language according to groups of related meanings. It is useful for showing the synonym of each word.

form.definition: determiner These is the plural of this. These biscuits are really tasty.
pronoun These is the plural of this. These are my children, Sophie and Andrew.
noun A thesis is a long essay based on research which a student presents for a higher degree at a university.
noun A thesis is an opinion that someone puts forward for discussion or debate. His thesis is that decreasing taxes will actually increase revenue.
pronoun They is the pronoun used for two or more people not including the speaker or listener, or two or more things. I have a brother and a sisterthey are both older than me.
pronoun You can also use they to refer to people in general. They say the cost of housing will rise. At last they've started work on the new bypass.
pronoun In informal language, you can use they instead of 'he or she'. If anyone is late, they'll be left behind.

adjective If a flat thing is thick, it has a larger than normal distance from top to bottom or from one side to the other. That's a very thick book you're reading. The letter was too thick to go under the door. She cut a thick slice of bread. I put on a thick woollen jumper.
adjective If something is thick, the parts it is made of are packed closely together. It is dense. We got scratched walking through the thick bush. It was hard to see anything through the thick fog.
adjective If a liquid is thick, it doesn't flow or pour easily. It is not runny. This soup is too thick for my liking.
adjective You use thick to state the amount that something flat measures from top to bottom or from one side to the other. The ice on the lake was ten centimetres thick.
adjective In informal language, if you say someone is thick, you mean that they are stupid. They are not intelligent. She must be thick not to realise it was a joke.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE for senses 1, 2 and 3 is thin. ... WORD FAMILY verb thicken Stir the sauce until it thickens. The fog thickened rapidly.adverb thickly Slice the potatoes thickly and fry them in oil.noun thickness The paper's thickness makes it hard to cut. Use a double thickness of card.

form.definition: noun A thicket is a group of small trees or shrubs growing close together.
noun A thief is someone who steals. The police recovered my car but they never caught the thief. He has been a petty thief since his teens.
noun The thigh is the top part of a leg. This is an exercise to trim your hips and thighs. I pulled a muscle in my thigh.
noun A thimble is a metal, china or plastic cover you can put on the end of your index finger when you're sewing, to protect it from being pricked by the needle.

adjective If a flat thing is thin, it has a smaller than normal distance from top to bottom or from one side to the other. The dictionary is printed on very thin paper. You must be cold in that thin dress.

adjective If something is thin, the parts it is made of are packed loosely together. It is not dense. We flew through some thin cloud. It's only a thin drizzle. The higher we climbed, the thinner the vegetation became.
adjective If a liquid is thin, it flows or pours easily. It is runny. I still feel pretty nauseous, but I could face a thin soup. The paint was too thin and dripped everywhere.
adjective If a person is thin, they don't have much flesh on their body. I wish I was thinner. She looks so thin and pale. ... THE OPPOSITE of this is fat.
adjective If something is thin, there is not very much to it. It is not substantial. The evidence to support this theory is thin. His report was rather thin on recommendations.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE for senses 1, 2 and 3 is thick. ... WORD FAMILY verb thin (thinned, thinning) The crowd began to thin. Thin the sauce with chicken stock.adverb thinly Slice the bread as thinly as you can. Her curiosity was thinly veiled.noun thinness Her thinness was pitiful to see.

form.definition: noun A thing is an object that is not a person or an animal. Verbs refer to actions and nouns refer to things.
noun You can use thing to refer vaguely to any object, event or idea. What's that plastic thing for? A dreadful thing happened yesterday.
a thing You can use a thing instead of anything in negative sentences in order to emphasise it. I can't do a thing about it. He was so sick he couldn't eat a thing.

one of those things If you say something is one of those things, you mean that things like it just happen sometimes, and that they cannot be explained or that it's not worth worrying about them. They fell in loveit was one of those things. 'I'm dreadfully sorry about breaking your glass.' 'Never mind, it's just one of those things.'
the thing If you say something is the thing, you mean that it is fashionable or popular. Discos are no longer the thing with young people.

the thing is You can say the thing is to introduce a reason for something or a problem that you are concerned about. I'm afraid I can't come to your partythe thing is I've promised to visit my sister then. It's not that I don't want tothe thing is how we're going to pay for it.
things (a) Things can refer to life in general. How are things with you? I've been getting a bit depressed about things lately. Things will work out just fine, you wait and see.

(b) Your things are your possessions or your clothes. Put your things in the bedroom and I'll show you around. There isn't room in the new unit for all my things. I got out of my wet things and took a hot shower.

verb When you think, you form an idea in your mind. I often think about my friends back home. I tried to think what to do next. Think carefully before you make a decision. One person thinks of a word and the others try to guess it.
