verb If you think that something is the case, that is your opinion but you are not absolutely certain or you do not have definite proof. I think I'm getting a cold. He's already left for the office, I think. When do you think it will be ready? She thinks she's absolutely perfect. I don't think so, I know so.
verb If you think of something, you remember it. I often think of those happy times we spent together. I can't think where I've seen her before. Try to think where you left your glasses.
verb If you are thinking of doing something, you are considering doing it. We're thinking of going to see a movie tonightwould you like to come? I think I'll go for a walk later.

verb If you think of someone, you bear them in mind. He's so selfishhe never thinks of anyone but himself. Thanks for the postcardit was nice of you to think of me. Don't eat all the cakethink of other people.
verb If you think of someone or something in a certain way, you have an opinion about them.

7 think a lot In informal language, if you think a lot of someone, you are fond of them; if you think a lot of something, you are impressed by it. I've always thought kindly of her since she helped me. What do you think of my new haircut? I didn't think much of the movie.
think better of If you think better of something, you decide not to do it after all. You change your mind about doing it. Heinrich was going to write an angry letter but he thought better of it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See thought.noun thinker He is one of the greatest thinkers of the twentieth century.noun thinking He tried to persuade her to his way of thinking.

form.definition: adjective The third person or thing is the one which comes next in order after the second. He was third in the queue after Joe and me. Which is the third longest river in the world?
noun A third is one of three equal parts of something. Twenty minutes is a third of an hour.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb thirdly

form.definition: noun Thirst is the feeling that you have when you want something to drink. Here's a long cool drink to quench your thirst. Many animals died of thirst during the drought.
noun A thirst for something is an eager desire for it. Jason's always got his nose in a bookhe has such a thirst for knowledge. Her thirst for adventure took her all over the world.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective thirsty (thirstier, thirstiest) The salty food has made me thirsty.

form.definition: noun Thirteen is the number 13, ten plus three.
adjective If you have thirteen things, the number of things you have adds up to thirteen.
adjective The thirteenth person or thing is the one which comes next in order after the twelfth.
noun A thirteenth is one of thirteen equal parts of something.
noun Thirty is the number 30, ten times three.
adjective If you have thirty things, the number of things you have adds up to thirty.
thirties The thirties in the twentieth century is the decade from 1930 to 1939, in the nineteenth century from 1830 to 1839, and so on.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective thirtieth

form.definition: determiner This is used to point out a particular person or thing. I like this colour best. These flowers are for your birthday.
determiner You use this to refer to the person or thing which is nearer in place or time.
pronoun You can use this to refer to a particular person or thing. This is the friend I was telling you about. Who did this?
adverb This is also used with adjectives and adverbs of quantity to say exactly how much. Since we've come this far, let's go on. Add about this much sugar.
noun Thistles are wild plants with prickly leaves. The garden was overgrown with thistles.
noun A thong is a narrow strip of leather or other material. The panels of the tent are bound together with leather thongs.
noun A thong is a simple sandal which is held on the foot by a strap passing between the toes. They don't let people into the hotel wearing thongs. NOT-SHIRTS, NO THONGS![qr

dictionary.entry:
thornT@:n
noun A thorn is a sharp pointed growth on the stem of a plant. I broke off the thorns before I put the roses in a vase. ... WORD FAMILY adjective thorny (thornier, thorniest)

form.definition: adjective If you are thorough in doing something, you do it very carefully so as not to miss anything. Sean's a thorough workerhe can check the files.
adjective If an action is thorough, it is done carefully and completely. The kitchen needs a thorough clean.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb See thoroughly.noun thoroughness adverb thoroughly

form.definition: noun A thoroughfare is a public road or pathway which is open at both ends. NO THOROUGHFARE
adverb If you do something thoroughly, you do it carefully or completely. The new edition of the textbook has been thoroughly revised and brought up to date.
adverb Thoroughly also means 'completely' or 'utterly'. By now we were all thoroughly soaked. I'm thoroughly fed up with the whole thing.
determiner Those is the plural of that. That rose looks alright but those daisies need water.
pronoun Those is the plural of that. That book is minethose over there are his.

conjunction Though means 'in spite of the fact that'. You often use even though as a more emphatic form. Another word for this is although. The fete went ahead even though it was raining. Though it's hard work, it's worthwhile.

adverb You can use though at the end of a sentence or phrase to show that it is in contrast with something that has just been said. It's an interesting job. It doesn't pay much, though. 'She's a firm supervisor.' 'Fair, though.'
verb Thought is the past tense of think.
noun Thought is the process of thinking or considering something. He sat lost in thought. Give it some thought before you decide. Her work is a major contribution to modern literary thought.
noun A thought is an idea that you have. The thought came to me that maybe he was right after all. I tried to put the thought out of my head. It seemed that she could read my thoughts.
adjective If someone is thoughtful, they are thinking hard about something. Nigel's been very thoughtful all dayI hope there's nothing wrong. She gave a thoughtful smile, and nodded.
adjective If someone is thoughtful, they are considerate. They are aware of other people's feelings. It was very thoughtful of you to remember my birthday.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb thoughtfully

form.definition: adjective If an action is thoughtless, it is done without proper consideration of the consequences.
noun A thousand is the number 1000, one hundred times ten.
adjective If you have a thousand things, the number of things you have adds up to a thousand.
adjective If something is the thousandth thing, it comes next in order after number nine hundred and ninety-nine.
noun A thousandth is also one of one thousand equal parts of something. It is 0.1% of it.
verb If someone thrashes a person or animal, they hit them hard and repeatedly, usually as a punishment. He threatened to thrash the children if they misbehaved.
verb If you thrash someone in a match or contest, you defeat them decisively. The home team was soundly thrashed in the finals.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun thrashing He got a thrashing for lying.[qr

dictionary.entry:
threadTrEd
noun A thread is a thin strand of cotton, silk, wool or other fibre. There's a loose thread on your jacket. ...a reel of thread.
noun The thread of an argument or story is the line of thought which runs through it. It was hard to pick up the thread, after missing the beginning of the lecture. I lost the thread of what she was saying.
noun The spiral ridge on a screw or at the top of a container is also called the thread.
verb If you thread a needle, you make a piece of thread go through its eye, so that you can use it to sew.

form.definition: adjective If a piece of clothing or cloth is threadbare, it is worn and thin. This coat is getting very threadbare. A threadbare rug lay on the bare wooden floor.
noun A threat is a warning that someone intends to harm you. He received a death threat in the mail.
noun A threat is someone or something that is a possible danger. He saw her competence as a threat to his authority. Cheap imports are a threat to the Australian manufacturing industry.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb See threaten.

form.definition: verb If someone threatens you, they warn you that they intend to harm you. Witnesses were threatened to prevent them from giving evidence. They threatened to kill his wife if he went to the police. He threatened violence if anyone tried to stop him.
verb If something threatens something, it puts it in possible danger. A rise in interest rates will threaten the economic recovery.
noun Three is the number 3, two plus one.
adjective If you have three things, the number of things you have adds up to three.

dictionary.entry: three-dimensionalTri:-d`mEnS@n@l adjective If something is three-dimensional, it has length, breadth and height. It is a solid object. ... NOTE The abbreviation for this is 3-D.

form.definition: verb When someone threshes corn, wheat or other cereal plants, they separate the grains from the rest of the plant by beating.
noun A threshold is the part of a doorway or entrance that you have to step over to go into a room or house. He knocked and waited on the threshold.

noun The threshold of an event or development is the stage just before it really begins. He was convinced he was on the threshold of an important discovery. I'm just at the threshold of being able to communicate properly in Japanese.

noun A threshold is also a level or limit beyond which something happens or is true. This time he's overstepped the threshold of my tolerance. Dogs can detect sounds that are outside the threshold of human hearing.
verb Threw is the past tense of throw.
noun Thrift is the careful management of money or resources. She'd learned thrift from living on a pension.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective thrifty (thriftier, thriftiest)

form.definition: noun A thrill is a strong feeling of excitement and nervousness, or something that makes you feel like that. I felt a huge thrill when I heard him announce that I'd won. The children loved the thrills of the funfair. My first ride in a plane was a real thrill.
verb If something thrills you, it makes you feel excited and happy. The clown thrilled the crowd with his antics.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See thriller.adjective thrilled I'm really thrilled that you'll be able to visit.adjective thrilling Australia won in the last minutes of a thrilling game.

form.definition: noun A thriller is an exciting story or film about crime, adventure and mystery.
verb If people or things thrive, they grow or develop well. After going through difficult times, his business is now thriving. 'How are your kids?' 'Oh, they're all thriving.'
noun Your throat is the front part of your neck. She had a large bruise on her throat.
noun Your throat is also the passage from your mouth to your stomach and lungs. I've got a sore throat.

force something down someone's throat If you force something down someone's throat, you try to make them accept it whether they want to or not. They were fed up with having political propaganda forced down their throat.
verb When your heart throbs, you are very aware of its beating. My heart throbbed with excitement.
verb If a part of your body throbs, it is very sore with a pain that comes in waves like a pulse. My head throbbed with pain. I can't wait to rest my throbbing feet.
noun A throne is the special chair a king or queen uses on ceremonial occasions.
noun The throne means the power or authority of a king or queen. Queen Elizabeth II came to the throne in 1952. He accused his opponent of being disloyal to the throne.
noun A throng is a large crowd of people. Throngs lined the streets to watch the parade. I can't face the throngs at the January sales.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb throng Tourists thronged the city square.

form.definition: verb If someone throttles someone else, they grab them by their neck and choke or strangle them. The victim had been throttled. Gina's so tactlesshonestly, I could throttle her!
noun A throttle is a device like a valve which controls the flow of petrol or steam. The drivers really opened the throttle in the last stretch of the race.
preposition If something moves through something, it moves from one end or side of it to the other. The main road runs through the town. The water had soaked through the tent.

preposition If something happens through a period of time, it happens from the beginning to the end. I hate having to sit through boring lectures. I heard him snoring through the night. ...to go through life.
preposition If something happens through something else, it happens as a result of it or by means of it. She missed the party through illness. He got the job through a friend.
preposition If you can see, hear, or feel through something, you are aware of something on the other side of it. It is difficult to see through thick fog. We could hear voices through the wall.
adverb Through means in at one end or side and out the other. They wouldn't let us through without tickets. The paper was too thickthe pin wouldn't go through.
adverb Through also means from beginning to end. Read this through carefully.
7 get through If you get through something, you come to the end of it. They got through a month's work in three weeks.
go through If you go through something, you use it up or wear it out. We go through two litres of milk a day. I've gone through three pairs of pantihose in a couple of days.

go through with If you go through with a task, you continue doing it until it's finished. 10 through with (a) If you are through with a task, you have finished doing it. I'm through with the washing up now.
(b) If you are through with a thing, you have finished using it. Are you through with the hammer yet?
(c) If you say you are through with something, you mean you are tired of it and have given up in disgust. I'm through with this awful job, I really am!

preposition If something happens throughout a place or period of time, it happens in every part or at every time within it. There were signs of unrest throughout the country. She has been very active throughout her life.
adverb If something happens or is true throughout, it applies to all parts or times. The building is airconditioned throughout. Mona had been exceptionally brave throughout.

verb If you throw something, you cause it to move through the air by a sudden movement of your arm. They were throwing the ball to each other. The rioters threw stones at the police. Let's see who can throw a stick the furthest.

verb If you throw something somewhere, you put it there quickly or carelessly. I'll just throw on a jumper. He threw off his shoes and sat down. Throw your things on the bed and come and join the party.
verb If you throw a party, you arrange it and host it. I decided to throw a party to celebrate.

verb In informal language, if you say something throws you, you mean that it confuses or disturbs you. The unexpected phone call really threw meI didn't know how to react. Ann's pretty coolshe doesn't let anything throw her.
throw away (a) If you throw something away, you dispose of it or discard it. You get rid of it. Can we throw away this pile of old magazines? Well, if you're throwing away the vase, I'll have it.

(b) If you throw away something useful, you waste it. He had the opportunity but he threw it away. It was a shame to see her throw away all that hard work by dropping out just before the end. He throws away his money on trash.
throw in (a) If someone throws something in with what you buy, they let you have that extra thing free. We bought a lounge suite and had the coffee table thrown in.
(b) If you throw something in, you give up trying to succeed at it. You admit defeat. He found the science course too difficult and threw it in.

throw out (a) If you throw something out, you dispose of it or discard it. You get rid of it. When I moved I threw out several boxes of junk. (b) If someone throws you out of somewhere, they evict you. They force you to leave. The manager called the security guards to throw out the troublemakers. Your landlord can't just throw you out without proper notice.
throw over If you throw something over, you abandon it or give it up. He threw over his job to go travelling. She threw him over for another man.
throw up In informal language, if you say someone throws up, you mean they vomit.

throw yourself into If you throw yourself into something, you take part in it enthusiastically. Sheena really enjoyed the course and she threw herself into her studies. After his wife died he threw himself into his work to hide the pain.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun throw She won the javelin event with a world record throw.

form.definition: verb If you thrust something somewhere, you push it hard. He thrust his fists angrily into his pockets. A knife had been thrust into her back. She thrust her way through the crowds.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun thrust With one final thrust I dislodged the obstruction.

form.definition: noun A thud is a dull heavy sound that something makes when it falls or it strikes against something. The panel fell to the ground with a thud. There was a sickening thud as her head hit the table.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb thud (thuds, thudded, thudding) He thudded heavily down the stairs.

form.definition: noun A thug is someone who is rough and violent. He was beaten up by thugs on his way home.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective thuggish We will not tolerate this thuggish behaviour.

form.definition: noun Your thumb is the short, thick finger on the inner side of each of your hands. Carla still likes to suck her thumb.
all thumbs If you say someone is all thumbs, you mean that they are clumsy or awkward. I just can't thread this fine needleI seem to be all thumbs.

thumb a lift If you thumb a lift, you stand by the side of a road and signal with your thumb to drivers passing by that you want a free ride. Another word for this is hitchhike. He had no money left so he had to thumb a lift back to the city.

thumb through If you thumb through a book or magazine, you turn over the pages quickly to see if there is anything interesting in it to read. 'Have you finished reading that book already?' 'No, I just thumbed through it.' She sat in the waiting room thumbing through a magazine.
under someone's thumb If you are under someone's thumb, you are totally under their influence and control. You behave exactly as they want you to. She's got her son completely under her thumb.
verb If you thump something, you hit it hard. I thumped the rug to get the dust out. He threatened to thump the boy if he kept interrupting. She thumped her fist on the table and demanded service.
verb If something thumps, it makes a dull sound. The box thumped onto the floor. He came thumping along the corridor. My heart was thumping with excitement.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun thump He gave his son a hearty thump on the back. The brick landed with a thump.

form.definition: noun Thunder is the loud, explosive noise that follows a flash of lightning. Giselle was frightened by the thunder. ...a bolt of thunder.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb thunder We could hear it thundering in the distance.adjective thunder ...a thunder storm. ...a thunder bolt.adjective thunderous The walls collapsed with a thunderous crash.adjective thundery The forecast is for thundery showers.

form.definition: noun Thursday is the fourth day of the working week. It follows Wednesday.
adverb Thus is a formal word which means 'like this'. Slide the catch to the right thus.
adverb Thus also means 'so' or 'consequently'. New technology will reduce production time, thus increasing profitability.

verb If you thwart someone, you prevent them from succeeding in what they are trying to do. If you thwart an action, you prevent it from happening. He grew increasingly frustrated as his opponent repeatedly thwarted him. Our plan to windsurf was thwarted by the storm.
noun Thyme is an aromatic herb used in cooking.
noun Your thyroid or thyroid gland is an organ in your neck which produces a substance that affects your body's growth and activity.
noun A tick is the regular sound made by a clock or watch. I was soothed by the tick of the clock.
noun A tick is a written mark (;ck) that you make to show that something is correct or accounted for.
noun In informal language, a tick is a very short period of time. It is a moment. Wait a tick, I'll come with you. I'll be ready in a tick. This will only take a tick.
noun A tick is a small blood-sucking insect.
tick off In informal language, if you say someone ticks you off, you mean that they reprimand you or scold you. The boss ticked me off for being late again.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb tick I could hear the clock ticking. She ticked off my name on the list.

form.definition: noun A ticket is a small piece of paper or card which shows that you have paid to travel on a bus, train, or plane, or to see a film, play or other entertainment.
noun A ticket is also a small tag that shows the price or size of something for sale.
verb When you tickle someone, you scratch them lightly on sensitive parts of their body to make them laugh. She tickled the baby's feet affectionately.
noun If your nose or throat tickles, you have a feeling or irritation or itching there that makes you want to sneeze or cough.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See ticklish.noun tickle I've got a tickle in my throatI hope I'm not getting a cold.

form.definition: adjective If someone is ticklish, they are sensitive to being tickled, and can easily be made to laugh. They say that being ticklish is a sign of a sensual person.
adjective If a situation or problem is ticklish, it is awkward and needs to be handled carefully. The chair had to answer some ticklish questions at the meeting.

dictionary.entry: tiddly`tIdli:tiddliertiddliest adjective In informal language, if you say that someone is tiddly, you mean that they are slightly drunk. No more wine, thanksI don't want to get tiddly.

form.definition: noun The tide is the regular rise and fall, twice a day, of the ocean. We sat on the beach and watched the tide coming in. High tide is at about nine o'clock this morning.
noun The tide of opinion or fashion is the way in which people in general change their views over time. The tide of public opinion has turned against the government.

tide over If something tides you over, it is enough to keep you going until you can get more supplies. If you tide someone over, you give them what they need to get by for the moment. This litre of milk should tide us over till I go to the shops. I don't get paid for another three daysI'll have to ask mum to tide me over.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective tidal The lower parts of the river are tidal.

form.definition: adjective If something is tidy, it is neat and in good order. She always keeps her desk tidy. You look much tidier with your hair tied back.
adjective A tidy person is in the habit of keeping everything neat and in good order. He's the tidiest person I knownothing's ever out of place in his room.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb tidy (tidies, tidied, tidying) He tidied his desk. I tidied up the room. She tidied away the papers.

form.definition: verb If you tie something, you hold it in place with string or rope. The robbers tied his hands to the chair. The parcel was neatly wrapped and tied.

verb If you tie something such as string or rope, you loop it into a knot or bow. I stopped to tie my shoelaces. She tied a ribbon in her hair. He tied a big red bow round the present. Tie the knot as tight as you can. She wore a scarf tied round her neck.
verb If you tie with someone in a competition, you come equal with them. You get the same score or mark. Mona tied with Nita for first place in the English exam. The teams tied with 38 points each.

noun A tie is a narrow decorative band of cloth which is worn under the collar of a shirt and knotted at the front so that the ends hang down. Another, rather old-fashioned, word for this is necktie. The men were formally dressed, in suits and ties.
noun A tie is something that you have a responsibility to devote time and attention to. Sue doesn't have time for sportshe has too many other ties. He turned down the transfer because of family ties.
tie down If something ties you down, it restricts your freedom. It prevents you from doing things that you would like to do. She's really tied down with four young children to look after.

tie in If something ties in with something else, it fits well with it or is linked. The editor wants pictures that will tie in with the travel theme. I wonder if his absence ties in with what he was saying last week about looking for a new job.
tie up (a) When a ship or boat ties up at a jetty or dock, ropes or cables from it are tied round strong posts so that it is secure.
(b) If things tie up together, they are closely connected or linked. Her evidence tied up with what the other witness claimed to have seen.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun tie Nobody wonit was a tie.

form.definition: noun A tier is one of a set of rows or levels that are arranged one above the other. The new stadium has twenty tiers of seats. It is traditional to save one tier of the wedding cake for the christening of the first child.
noun The tiger snake is a poisonous Australian snake which has striped markings.
adjective If something is tight, it is firm and secure. I can't unscrew the lidit's too tight. Be sure to make the knots good and tight. She kept a tight grasp on the child's arm.
adjective If something is tight, it fits very closely. He's grown so much that his clothes are too tight now. New shoes often feel tight at first. She thinks she looks sexy in her tight jeans.

adjective If something is tight, there is no free room or time. It was a tight squeeze getting the lounge through the doorway. My schedule is very tight over the next couple of weeks. We just caught the plane, but it was pretty tight.

adjective In informal language, if you say someone is tight, you mean they are not generous with their money. They are stingy. He never offers to shout drinkshe's too tight. Come on, don't be tightlet's buy the bigger one.
adjective In informal language, if you say someone is tight, you mean they are drunk. He got tight at the party and embarrassed us all.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb tighten She tightened her grasp on the child's arm.adverb tightly I clutched the parcel tightly. The suitcase was tightly packed.noun tightness He felt a tightness in his chest.

form.definition: noun Tights are like a pair of stockings that are joined together at the top and cover your legs from your waist down to your feet.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is pantihose.

form.definition: noun Tiles are thin clay slabs used to cover surfaces such as roofs, floors or walls. The storm blew a couple of tiles off the roof. She bought expensive Italian tiles to decorate the bathroom. A mosaic is a design made from small coloured tiles set in plaster.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb tile The next job is to tile the bathroom.

form.definition: preposition Till means 'up to' a certain time. Another word for this is until. You may keep it till tomorrow. I won't be back till May.
conjunction Till means 'up to the time when'. Another word for this is until. I'll wait here till you get back. Don't start till I tell you to.
noun A till is a drawer in a cash register where the money is kept. The boss thinks that Roberto's been taking money from the till.
verb When someone tills land, they grow crops on it.

verb If something tilts or you tilt it, it moves from being upright or flat to a slanting or sloping position. Be careful not to tilt the glass or you'll spill your drink. I almost lost my balance as the ship tilted.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun tilt He wore his cap with a tilt to one side.

form.definition: noun Timber is wood that has been sawn up and prepared for use in building. Jim has bought the timber for the pergola.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective timber It's a brick house with a timber attic.

form.definition: noun Time is the passing of hours, days and years, in the past, present and future. Time goes slowly when you're bored. We must act soontime is running out.

noun The time is a particular moment, as shown by a clock. 'What's the time?' 'It's half past six.' Jennifer is too young to tell the time yet. What time do you get up in the morning? I'd like to talk to youis now a good time?
noun If you say it's time to do something, you mean it ought to be done now. It's time to leave if you want to catch that bus. I decided that it was time for a new haircut.
noun If you have a good time or a bad time, you have a pleasant or unpleasant experience or period in your life. We had a wonderful time at the party. It was a bad time for me when my husband died.
all the time If something happens all the time, it happens continually or very often. How can I concentrate with that baby crying all the time? I'm fed up with the way she nags me all the time.

6 in time If something happens in time, it happens when it needs to for the sake of something else. It is not too late. I nearly missed the train, but I got to the station just in time. Are we in time for the start of the movie? If you hurry, you'll be in time to catch him before he leaves.
on time If something happens on time, it happens at the correct time. It is neither early nor late. Our bus arrived on time.[xp\start\[ap--timely
adjective If something is timely, it happens at just the right time. We'd have been in big trouble if it hadn't been for your timely arrival.
noun A timetable is a list of the times when buses, trains or planes arrive or leave.
noun A timetable is a plan showing the days and times when events will take place.
adjective Someone who is timid is shy or easily frightened. When I was young, I was too timid to argue with anyone.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun timidity I'm glad you've overcome your timidity!adverb timidly

form.definition: noun Tin is a silver-coloured metal.
noun A tin is a metal container. You can buy food in sealed tins. We opened a tin of peaches for dessert.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for sense 2 is can. ... WORD FAMILY adjective tinned Use fresh or tinned tomatoes.

form.definition: noun Tinea is a skin disease that people sometimes get between their toes.
noun A tinge of a colour is a faint appearance of that colour. There was a tinge of red in the evening sky.
noun A tinge is also a slight degree of any quality or feeling. Did I hear a tinge of envy in your voice?
verb If part of your body tingles, you have a prickling feeling there. My fingers tingled when I touched the wire.
verb If you tingle with excitement, you feel very excited.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun tingle A tingle of excitement ran through her body.

form.definition: verb If you tinker with something, you spend time trying to mend or repair it, usually without success. Tony's always tinkering with his old car.
verb If something tinkles, it makes a light, ringing sound. Did you hear the phone tinkle just then?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun tinkle

form.definition: noun In informal language, a tinnie is a can of beer.
adjective We say something sounds tinny if it has a high-pitched metallic sound. I could hear old tunes being thumped out on a tinny piano.
adjective Something that is tinny is not made well and doesn't last long. Dents soon appeared in his new toy truckit was tinny and cheap.
noun Tinsel is a decoration made out of shiny, metallic strips or threads, and used especially at Christmas.
noun A tint is a colour, especially one that you mix in with a main colour to change it. Maria came back from the hairdresser with a rather nice tint in her hair.
verb If you tint your hair, you change its colour by putting a special dye in it.
adjective Someone or something that is tiny is extremely small. I need glasses to read such tiny print. ...a tiny little baby.
noun The tip of a long, thin object is the end of it. I burnt the tip of my tongue. The tips of my fingers were numb with cold. Use a needle with a finer tip. ...the tip of a pencil.
verb If you tip an object, you move it out of a horizontal or upright position.

verb If you tip something somewhere, you pour it there by quickly tipping its container. Tip the stale beer into the sink. The truck driver tipped the load of soil into the front yard. She tipped everything out of her bag and onto the desk.
noun A tip is a place for dumping rubbish. He loaded up the trailer with stuff to take to the tip.
noun A tip is money that you give to someone such as a waiter to show that you have appreciated their services. Ron always gives the taxi driver a $2 tip.
tip over If you tip something over or if it tips over, it turns over or falls over. The cup tipped over and the tea spilt on the tablecloth.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb tip Are you going to tip the waiter?

form.definition: adjective Someone who is tipsy is slightly drunk. Jane felt a bit tipsy after just one glass of champagne.
noun A tirade is a long, angry speech criticising someone or something. The opposing candidates in the council election are increasing their tirades against each other.

verb If something tires you, you want to rest or sleep because it makes you lose a lot of energy. A hectic day of sightseeing really tired the tourists. After driving for five hours Bill started to tire.
verb If you tire of something, you get bored with it. Eventually she tired of his frequent visits. He quickly tired of eating sandwiches for lunch and started buying hot meals.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See tired.

form.definition: adjective If you are tired, you feel that you would like to rest or sleep. You can also say that your eyes or voice are tired if they show that you are tired. After a long day at work he was tired. The tired tourists were grateful for the short tea break. He rubbed his tired eyes and tried to keep studying.
adjective If you are tired of something, you are bored with it. I'm tired of the same old sandwiches for lunch. Louise was tired of going to parties with her husband's colleagues.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun tiredness

form.definition: adjective Something that is tiring makes you tired. I've had a tiring day at the office. The trip was very tiring and we went straight to bed when we got home.
noun Tissue is the mass of cells that form the various parts of a plant or animal. Each part has cells that are similar in appearance or function. ...lung tissue. ...muscle tissue. ...scar tissue.
noun A tissue is a square piece of soft paper that you use for blowing your nose on. ...a box of tissues.
tissue paper Tissue paper is thin paper for wrapping things that can get damaged easily, such as crockery or glass.
noun In informal language, a tit is a woman's breast.
noun A titbit is a small piece of tasty food. The waiter brought around a tray of interesting titbits.
noun A title is a name given to a book, play, painting or piece of music. 'Pride and Prejudice' is the title of a classic novel by Jane Austen.
noun A title is a term that is used to sation. Anne's new title is 'Senior Manager, Marketing'.

noun Someone's title is also a word that is used before their family name when speaking to or about them. It indicates their status and you can use it in rather formal situations, especially if you do not know them personally.
form.note: ... COMMON TITLES include Mr, Mrs, Doctor and Professor.

form.definition: noun A titter is a short laugh that shows you are nervous or embarrassed. I wish he'd stop that irritating titter of his.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb titter The guests tittered at his awful joke.

dictionary.entry:
totu: when stressed or before a vowel; otherwise
preposition You use to when indicating the direction or place towards which someone or something is moving. She hurried to the station. The road turned to the right. It fell to the ground with a thud. He's off to America next week.
preposition You use to when indicating how far something extends. Lucy can now count to ten. We got soaked to the skin in the sudden downpour. There was complete silence from beginning to end. They have not spoken to each other to this day.
3 preposition You use to when indicating that something happens until a certain time or limit is reached. The restaurant is open for lunch from Monday to Friday. To this day, Angela is grateful to him.
preposition You use to when indicating to whom or what an action is directed. He waved good-bye to the cheering crowd. Do you do repairs to lawnmowers?
preposition You use to when expressing comparison. The standard has gone down, compared to what it was two years ago. I prefer classical music to jazz. This product is far superior to that.
preposition You use to when referring to time to mean 'before'. It's a quarter to five. Only two more days to the weekend! I'm hungry but it's still an hour to lunch.
preposition You use to when you mean 'in connection with'. Smoking is a danger to your health. The camera won't work. What have you done to it? There's more to managing a business than you think.
preposition You use to when a certain amount or quantity makes up something. There are one hundred cents to the dollar.
preposition You use to with words indicating a reaction. To my delight, he won the race. The government was defeated, to everyone's surprise. To his horror, he watched the car roll over the cliff.
to and fro If something moves to and fro, it moves from one place to another many times. He's always travelling to and fro between Sydney and Melbourne.

form.definition: noun A toad is an animal that looks like a frog but has a rough skin.
noun A toadstool is a poisonous type of fungus that looks like a mushroom.
noun Toast is sliced bread that has been cooked on both sides till it is crisp and brown. I have two pieces of toast with jam every morning for breakfast. ...sweet corn on toast.

noun When you drink a toast to someone, you wish them good health, success or happiness, and drink some wine or other alcoholic drink. He proposed a toast to the bride and groom. Let's drink a toast to the new year!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See toaster.verb toast

form.definition: noun A toaster is an electrical device for toasting bread.
noun Tobacco is a substance used for smoking in cigarettes, pipes and cigars.
noun A toboggan is a small vehicle used for sliding over snow.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb toboggan

form.definition: noun Today is this present day. Today is Monday. Today's Harold's birthday.
noun Today is also this present time or period in history. The young people of today are more independent than they were in the thirties.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb today Will it rain today? We rely more on computers today than ever before.

form.definition: verb If you toddle somewhere, you walk there with slow, unsteady steps, the way a small child walks. The old man toddled down the corridor to answer the doorbell.
noun A toddler is a small child who has only recently learned to walk. Gwen has two children, one at kindergarten and a toddler at home.
noun Your toes are the five small moveable parts at the end of your foot. These shoes are too smallthey're pinching my toes! Ouch! I've stubbed my big toe.
noun The toe of a shoe or sock is the part that covers the toes.

toe the line If you say that someone toes the line, you mean that they behave as they are expected to by someone in authority. If you don't toe the line, there is no place for you in this organisation.
adverb If you do something together with other people, you do it with them. They all went to school together. Barry and Alison travel to work together but come home separately.

adverb If you join things together, they are joined or fixed to each other. Never mind the broken platethe pieces can easily be glued together again. To make the handle longer you must screw together the two sections.
adverb If people or things are together, they are in the same place or close to each other. The men were called together to hear the announcement. Put your feet together and stand up straight.

4 together with Together with something else means 'in addition to' or 'as well as' the other. He handed her the parcel together with the receipt. Garry was invited to the party together with his sisters.
verb When you toil, you work for a long time doing something that is not easy or pleasant. Women were toiling in the fields planting rice.

noun A toilet is a large bowl that is fixed to the floor and connected to a drain. It has a seat and you use it when you need to get rid of faeces and urine from your body. PLEASE FLUSH THE TOILET AFTER USE
noun A toilet is also a small room where people go to use a toilet. The women's toilet is over there. ...public toilets.
form.note: ... OTHER WORDS for this are lavatory, restroom and, in informal language, gents (for a men's toilet), ladies (for a women's toilet) and loo.

form.definition: toilet paper Toilet paper is thin paper, usually in a roll, that you use to clean yourself after getting rid of faeces and urine from your body.
noun Toiletries are things that you use to clean or care for your body, such as soap, shampoo, toothpaste and deodorant. Are you sure you need so many toiletries? It's only an overnight trip.
noun A token is a ticket or disc that's made to be used instead of money to pay for something. For his farewell we gave Fred a $50 gift token.
noun A token is also a sign or symbol of something. He gave her a ring as a token of his love. Their black clothes are a token of their grief.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective token The small donation was just a token gesture. ...a token payment.

form.definition: verb Told is the past tense and past participle of tell.

adjective If something is tolerable, you are able to experience it or allow it to happen even though it is not pleasant or you do not like it. The food was excellent but the accommodation was just tolerable.
adjective If you are tolerant, you allow other people to do what they want even if you think it isn't good.
verb If you tolerate something you do not like or agree with, you allow it to happen. His parents would not tolerate bad manners. I cannot tolerate this noise any longer.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See tolerable.noun tolerance adjective See tolerant.

form.definition: noun A toll is a fee that you have to pay for using certain bridges, tunnels or expressways.

noun A toll is also the amount of damage that is caused by something. A death toll is the number of people killed in some disaster. Police are doing all they can to reduce the death toll on our roads.
take a toll If something takes a toll or takes its toll, it has a very damaging effect. It causes big losses. The drought was beginning to take its toll as more and more cattle were dying.
noun A tomato is a soft, juicy, red fruit that can be cooked as a vegetable or eaten raw in salads.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective tomato ...tomato sauce. ...tomato soup.

form.definition: noun A tomb is a large grave, especially one that has been decorated with a monument.
noun A tombstone is a flat stone placed over someone's grave or tomb. It usually has their name, date of birth and date of death on it. ... ANOTHER WORD for this is gravestone.
noun A tomcat is a male cat.
noun Tomorrow is the day after today. Tomorrow will be fine and sunny. We have a lot to do for tomorrow. Will it be published in tomorrow's paper?
noun Tomorrow can also mean the future. I wonder what the cars of tomorrow will look like?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb tomorrow He said he'd be late home tomorrow.

form.definition: noun A ton is a measure of weight equal to approximately 1016 kilograms. It is an old measure, now replaced by the tonne.

noun In informal language, if you say that you have a ton or tons of something, you mean you have a very large quantity of it. There's a ton of milk in the fridgehelp yourself. She complained that she had tons of work still to do.
3 weigh a ton In informal language, if you say that something weighs a ton, you mean that it is very heavy. What have you packed in this suitcase? It weighs a ton!
noun The tone of a musical instrument or sound is the quality it has. Your piano has a better tone than mine. The phone gave out the engaged tone.

noun The tone of your voice is the quality in your voice which you use to express a particular feeling or meaning. We knew he was angry from the tone of his voice. The doctor's tone was serious. He spoke with a sarcastic tone.

noun The tone of something can also be the general quality or nature of something. There was much arguing and the tone of the meeting was not friendly. The pessimistic tone of the diagnosis left us with little hope.
noun The tone of a colour is one of its shades. I would have chosen a lighter tone of green for the walls of this room. The picture is painted in warm tones.
lower the tone If something lowers the tone of a place, it makes it less attractive or acceptable. Rowdy behaviour in the streets can lower the tone of the neighbourhood.
noun Your tongue is the organ inside your mouth that you move around when you are eating or speaking.
noun A tongue is a language. The announcement was in a foreign tongue that Martha couldn't understand. 'What's your native tongue?' 'Chinese.'

3 on the tip of your tongue If you say that a word is on the tip of your tongue, you mean that you cannot remember it just now but will think of it soon. I should know his nameit's on the tip of my tongue.
4 tongue-tied If someone is tongue-tied, they are unable to speak because they are very shy, nervous or afraid. She was overwhelmed with emotion and became quite tongue-tied.

noun A tonic is something, especially a medicine, that makes you feel healthier, happier or stronger. I've been feeling so tired lately. Can you recommend a good tonic? Her cheerfulness is like a tonic to the rest of us.
tonic water Tonic water or tonic is a colourless, gassy drink with a slightly bitter taste that is often added to strong alcoholic drinks. Two gin and tonics for this table, please.
noun Tonight is the evening or night of this present day.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb tonight Would you like to play chess tonight?

form.definition: noun A tonne is a measure of mass that is equal to 1000 kilograms.
noun Your tonsils are the two small lumps at the back of your throat. She had a very sore throat and her tonsils looked inflamed.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See tonsilitis.

form.definition: noun Tonsilitis is an infection of the tonsils. It can be rather painful.
adverb You use too to indicate that something is included as well. Don't leave me behindI want to come too. They could speak English and French too.

adverb You use too to indicate that there is more than enough, or a lot more of something than is necessary. This coffee is too hot to drink. You're walking much too fast for me to keep up. We arrived too latethe train had already left. It's too good a bargain to miss.

3 adverb Too can also mean 'very' when it is used in a negative phrase. 'How are you today?' 'Not too bad.' It's not too expensive for you, is it? We want to buy a house in the not too distant future.
verb Took is the past tense of take.
noun A tool is a simple instrument, such as a hammer, knife or spade, that you hold in your hands to do a particular job. He keeps his[qrgarden tools in a shed.
noun A tool is also anything used like a tool to produce some result. Books are a tool for teaching.
verb When a horn or whistle toots or is tooted, it produces short blasts of sound. The train tooted twice and pulled out of the station.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun toot She waved and gave the horn a toot.

form.definition: noun Your teeth are the hard, white things inside your mouth that you use for biting and chewing food. He lost a front tooth in a sporting accident. Have you brushed your teeth yet?
noun The teeth of a comb, saw or rake are the narrow, pointed parts standing in a row.
3 have a sweet tooth If you have a sweet tooth, you are fond of sweet and sugary food. I can never say no to a chocolateI have a sweet tooth.
4 long in the tooth If you say that someone is long in the tooth, you mean that they are old. She's a bit too long in the tooth to be playing the part of a young girl.
noun A toothache is the pain that you feel when one of your teeth is not in good condition.
noun A toothbrush is a small brush that you use for cleaning your teeth.
noun Toothpaste is a thick substance that you put on a toothbrush when you clean your teeth.
noun A toothpick is a small wooden or plastic stick that you use to get food out from between your teeth.
noun The top of something is its highest part. We stopped for a rest at the top of the hill. He climbed to the top of the ladder. Start reading from the top of page ten.
noun If you are at the top of something, you are the best or most important. She works hard to stay at the top of the class. The guest of honour sat at the top of the table with the hosts.
noun The top of a bottle, jar or box is a covering or lid for it. Put the top back on the jam jar so ants don't get in.
noun A top is a piece of clothing worn on the upper part of the body. She wore shorts and a sleeveless top.
noun A top is also a toy that you can spin on its end.
verb If something tops something else, it is greater, better or higher. Your score tops mine by ten points. The company topped last year's profits by two million dollars.

7 on top of (a) If something is located on top of something else, it is placed on or over its highest part. The cat was lying on top of the bed. He put his empty plate on top of the others. (b) If something happens on top of something else, it happens in addition to it. I missed the bus, was late for work, and on top of that I left my lunch at home.
(c) If you say you are on top of some task or situation, you mean that you have it under control. You are coping with it well. I can't go anywhere until I get on top of all this work.
8 over the top If you say that something is over the top, you mean that it is exaggerated or not reasonable. I hope he doesn't go over the top with his dirty jokes.
9 tops In informal language, if you say that something is tops, you mean that it is the best. You like it very much. 'Do you like this flavour?' 'It's tops.' This latest CD really is the tops.

10 top up If you top up a container, you add more liquid to it to make it full again. Check the tyres and top up the petrol tank before you set off on your trip. Can I top up your glass with more wine?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective top ...a top drawer. ...top quality. ...a top price. ...the top floor.

form.definition: noun A topic is the subject of a conversation, talk, discussion or piece of writing. The topic of tonight's program is Antarctica. Here is a list of topics that will be covered next semester.
adjective A topical subject deals with things that are of interest to people at the present time. With elections approaching, the tax debate is topical.
adjective In medicine, a topical cream or ointment is one that is used on the surface of a part of the body. TOPICAL OINTMENTNOT TO BE TAKEN
adjective If a woman is topless, she isn't wearing anything to cover her breasts. The waitresses in the nightclub were topless.
noun A topping is food that can be put on top of other food to make it taste better or look better. The pudding was served with whipped cream and a topping of caramel sauce.
verb If something topples or is toppled, it becomes unsteady and falls down. The pile of books toppled over because it was too high.
noun A torch is an electric light which runs on batteries and is small enough to carry around. He shone the torch under the bed to find the missing toy.
verb Tore is the past tense of tear.

dictionary.entry:
torment`t@:mEnt for the noun; for the verb,t@:`mEnt
noun Torment is extreme suffering or unhappiness. A torment is something that causes this. His guilty feelings caused him a lot of torment. The bullies put William through various torments.
verb If someone or something torments you, they cause you suffering and pain, or they annoy you greatly. I've been tormented by migraines for years. All night we were tormented by mosquitoes. Stop tormenting me with your silly questions.
... WORD FAMILY noun tormentor

form.definition: verb Torn is the past participle of tear.
adjective A road or path that is tortuous is very twisted. It is full of bends. Puffing and panting, we followed the guide up the tortuous mountain track.

noun Torture is a deliberate act to cause someone severe pain and suffering in order to get information from them or to punish them. We read that in some countries torture is used on political prisoners.

verb If someone tortures another person, they deliberately cause severe pain to that person in order to get information from them or to punish them. Survivors of the war reported that many of their companions had been tortured and killed by the enemy.
verb If you toss something, you throw it lightly and carelessly. He tossed the rubbish into the bin.
verb If you toss your head, you move it with a jerk. She had a habit of tossing her head to get the hair out of her eyes.
verb If someone or something tosses or is tossed, they keep moving from side to side. The sick child tossed in his sleep all night. The ship was tossed in the rough seas.
verb If you toss a coin, you throw it in the air and decide something by guessing which side will be facing upwards after it lands on the ground. We tossed a coin to decide who should go first.
toss-up If you describe a situation as a toss-up, you mean that either of two possibilities is equally likely. It's a toss-up whether she'll accept my invitation.
noun A total is the number or quantity you get when you add up numbers or amounts. What is the total of that addition? A total of 2,000 people visited the exhibition on the first day.
adjective Something that is total is whole or entire. The total number of road deaths this year is less than last year. The total amount must not exceed $1,000.
adjective You use total to say that something is complete and absolute. They lived in total bliss. The lights went out and suddenly there was total darkness.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb total I'm trying to total the expenses. Our exports totalled $2 million.adverb totally She's totally dependent on her mother.

form.definition: adjective A totalitarian government is one which controls everything and does not allow political opposition. Germany under Hitler was a totalitarian regime.
noun A totem is a thing in nature, often an animal, which is used as an emblem by a family or tribe.
noun A totem is also a carving or drawing of such an emblem.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective totem The totem pole stood outside the hut.

form.definition: verb When someone totters, they walk with weak, unsteady steps. The old man tottered back to his bed.
verb If you touch something, you feel it with your hand or fingers. PLEASE DO NOT TOUCH THE GLASS Touch it and see if it is still cold.
verb If two things touch, they come into contact. The car was so small that the driver's head was touching the roof. I prefer long curtains that touch the floor.
verb If something touches you, or you are touched by something, you experience emotional feelings. He was touched by her sincerity. Her story touched us deeply.
noun Touch is the sense of feeling and is one of the five senses.
noun Touch is also the act of touching or being touched. Be carefulthe slightest touch will leave a mark.
noun A touch of something is a small amount or slight degree of it. Hilda was away from work todayshe has a touch of flu. There was a touch of spring in the air.

in touch (a) If you get in touch with someone, you communicate with them by writing to them or telephoning them. If you stay in touch with someone, you see them or speak with them regularly. I haven't heard from Miriam for agesI must get in touch with her. Don't forget to writewe must keep in touch.

(b) If you are in touch or keep in touch with a subject or situation, you are aware of the latest news or facts about it. You are up-to-date with it. Although he's been out of work for some time, he's kept in touch with his profession.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is to be out of touch or to lose touch.

form.definition: touch and go If you say that something is touch and go, you mean that the outcome is uncertain or risky. It's still touch and go whether the victim will survive the accident.
touch on If you touch on a subject, you talk or write about it briefly. He spoke at length without even touching on the real problems.

touch up If you touch something up, you make small changes to it to improve it. The essay is quite goodit just needs touching up here and there. If you touch it up with some paint, it will look brand new.
adjective If someone is touchy, they are irritable and can be easily upset or offended. Choose your words carefullyhe's the touchiest person I know.
adjective A touchy subject is one that needs to be treated carefully because it might upset someone. The rights of homosexuals is a touchy subject to discuss.
adjective Something that is tough is not easily broken or cut. It won't wear out quickly. This material is as tough as leather. ...tough glass.
adjective Meat that is tough is difficult to cut and eat. The steak was a bit tough but otherwise the meal was excellent.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is tender.

form.definition: adjective Someone or something that is tough is strong and able to handle bad conditions. They were trained to be tough soldiers. Four-wheel drive vehicles are tough and built for rough roads.
adjective A tough problem or job is a difficult one. That was the toughest exam I have ever sat for. The newly elected government has a tough time ahead of it.
adjective Policies or actions that are tough are strict. The headmaster insisted on tough discipline.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb toughen noun toughness

form.definition: noun A tour is a journey you go on for pleasure, during which you visit places of interest or different countries. We'll take our holidays next summer and go on a tour of Europe.
noun A tour is also a brief visit to or through a place to see it. The next guided tour of the palace will be at 2 p.m. A half-day sightseeing tour of the city is included in the itinerary.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb tour They're away at the moment touring New Zealand.

form.definition: noun Tourism is the business of providing services such as hotels, restaurants and sightseeing trips for tourists. Much of Fiji's income comes from tourism.
noun A tourist is a person who travels or tours for pleasure. The city square was crowded with large groups of tourists. I prefer to travel off-season when there are fewer tourists about.
noun A tournament is a competition where a series of games are played till there is one winner or winning team. ...a tennis tournament. ...a chess tournament.
verb If a vehicle tows another vehicle, it drags or pulls it along behind it. The car had to be towed to a garage for repairs.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun tow We gave the car a tow back to town.

form.definition: preposition If something or someone moves towards something else, they move in that direction. He turned towards me and smiled. The racing car sped towards the finish line. Face it towards the sun so it will dry faster.

preposition If someone or something moves towards a situation, it means that it is likely to happen. The company's new economic policy is heading towards disaster. Scientists are continually striving towards progress.
preposition Towards is used to mean 'with respect to' or 'as regards'. What is their attitude towards nuclear weapons? She is your little sister. Be kind towards her.
preposition If something happens towards a certain time, it happens shortly before that time. Towards evening there was a beautiful sunset. I think it happened towards the end of the last century.

preposition If you put money towards something, you pay it or save it for a particular purpose. His savings will go towards the deposit for a home unit. The donations will go towards education in underdeveloped countries.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING for this is toward.

form.definition: noun A towel is a piece of cloth used for wiping and drying something wet. ...a bath towel. ...a hand towel. ...a beach towel.
noun A tower is a tall, narrow structure. It can stand alone or be part of a large building. There is a revolving restaurant at the top of Centrepoint Tower in Sydney.
verb If something or someone towers, it rises to a great height. The skyscrapers towered above the city. He was the tallest in his class and towered over everyone else.
noun A town is a large area with houses, shops and offices where people live and work. It is smaller than a city but larger than a village.
noun Town is used to refer to the main shopping and business area of a town or city. I'm going to town tomorrow to see my solicitor. The bookshop in town has a larger range than my local store.
noun Town can be used to refer to the people of a town. The decision to build a new bridge has excited the whole town. The town will be celebrating its centenary next year.
noun Town can also be used to contrast living in a town with living in the country. I prefer the town to the country.

go to town If you say that someone goes to town doing something, you mean that they put a lot of effort or money into doing it. It was a special occasion and she really went to town with the decorations.
noun A town hall is a large building which belongs to a town and where public meetings can be held.
adjective A toxic substance is poisonous. The plastic gave off toxic fumes as it burned. ... WORD FAMILY noun See toxin.
noun A toxin is a poisonous substance.
noun A toy is an object for children to play with. The teddy bear was Angela's favourite toy. Don't play with the knifeit's not a toy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective toy ...a toy shop. ...a toy soldier. ...a toy gun.

form.definition: noun A trace is a mark or sign that shows that someone or something has been present. Police were looking for traces of evidence at the murder scene. The traces in the sand suggested that something had been dragged. They lost trace of their relatives during the war.
noun A trace of something is a very small amount of it. She found a trace of lipstick on the shirt. You could taste a trace of lemon in the water.

verb If you trace a person or thing, you find them by following their tracks or course. Doctors have traced the source of the epidemic to an illegal immigrant. The robber was traced as far as the border.
verb If you trace the development of something, you describe its course or history. She can trace her family history back to the 18th century.
verb If you trace a drawing, you cover it with transparent paper and then follow the lines of the original on it. Maps of countries are hard to draw; it's easier to trace them.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun tracing

form.definition: noun A track is a rough, narrow path. The track to the top of the mountain was overgrown and hard to follow.
noun A track is a mark or series of marks left by someone or something passing along. You could tell from the tracks in the mud that more than one car had been there.
noun A track is a course prepared for the racing of horses, cars or athletes. The athletes are taking their places on the track.
noun A track is the structure of metal rails and sleepers along which a train runs. The weekend rail service was disrupted because of maintenance work on the track.
noun A track is one of the sections or pieces of music on a record, tape or CD. The song you're looking for is on the third track.
noun A track is also the course or line of something as it travels. The expedition followed the track of the early explorers. The scientists followed the track of the spacecraft.
verb If you track a person or animal, you follow the track of their footprints to find them. Early Aborigines tracked animals to hunt them for food.
make tracks In informal language, if you say you have to make tracks, you mean that you have to leave or go home. Come on, it's very latewe must make tracks.
off the beaten track If something is off the beaten track, it is little known or secluded. I know a place for a quiet holidayit's out of town, off the beaten track.

on the right track In informal language, if you say that someone is on the right track, you mean that they have the right idea or plan for doing something. All the economic forecasts seem to confirm that we are on the right track with our policies. Let's get some feedback from our customers to make sure we're on the right track.
noun A tracksuit is a loose, warm set of clothing that you wear when you are doing physical exercises. It consists of a pair of trousers and a top.
noun A tractor is a powerful motor vehicle with large back wheels that is used to pull farm machinery.
noun Trade is the process of buying, selling or exchanging goods. The wool industry is hoping to increase its trade with China.
noun Someone's trade is the kind of work they do or the way they make their living. He's a carpenter by trade. You can learn many useful trades at the college.

verb When people, companies or countries trade, they buy, sell or exchange goods or other things. Australia trades with many Asian countries. A million dollars worth of shares were traded on the stock market this morning.

noun A trade-in is an item, usually a used one, that is given as part payment for a new one. The store took our old TV as a trade-in for a new one. With a trade-in the price of the new car was $10,000 less.
noun A trademark is a name or mark used by a company or manufacturer on its products.
noun A trade union is an organisation of workers set up to help its members with work problems such as wage increases and working conditions. ... WORD FAMILY noun trade unionist

noun A tradition is a custom or belief that has been handed down from one generation to another and practised for a long time. It is a European tradition to colour eggs at Easter time. ...a family tradition.
noun Tradition is also the passing down of customs, beliefs and stories from one generation to another. The Chinese culture is bound in tradition.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective traditional The dancers were dressed in traditional costume.adverb traditionally

form.definition: noun Traffic is the coming and going of people and vehicles along a road, waterway, railway or airway. There is always heavy traffic in peak hours.
noun Traffic is also the people and vehicles that travel along these different routes. The accident on the bridge caused a long bank-up of traffic.
verb Someone who traffics in drugs, arms or stolen goods buys and sells them illegally. Police suspect he's been trafficking in drugs.
noun A traffic jam is a situation where a road has become so crowded with traffic that the motor vehicles cannot move or can go only very slowly. Sorry I'm lateI was held up in a traffic jam.
noun A tragedy is a very sad or unfortunate event. Her life was marred with tragedies; first her mother died and then soon after that her sister.
noun A tragedy is a play for the theatre, cinema or TV that is very serious and has an unhappy ending.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See tragic.

form.definition: adjective Something that is tragic is very sad or unfortunate. They are trying to put their lives together after the tragic drowning of their child.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb tragically

form.definition: noun A trail is a path made across rough country.
noun A trail is the smell, footprints or other signs left by animals or persons as they move along. Police brought in dogs to find the trail of the lost child.
noun A trail is also a stream of smoke or dust left behind something moving. The steam-engine left a trail of smoke as it sped along. The plane left a vapour trail in the sky.
verb If you trail something or it trails, it drags along behind. The fisherman trailed a line behind the boat. Her long scarf trailed in the wind.
verb If you are trailing in a competition or game, you are falling behind your competitor. You have a lower score. At half-time our team was trailing by three goals.
noun A trailer is a vehicle that is made to be pulled by a motor vehicle. It is used to carry loads of things.
noun A trailer is a series of short extracts of a film or TV program which is shown to advertise it. From the trailer, it looks like a thrilling film.

noun A train is a number of railway carriages which are joined together and pulled along a railway line by an engine. When's the next train to the city? Let's go by train instead of bus to avoid the traffic.
verb If you train a person or animal to do something, you teach them how to do it. Flight attendants are trained to handle emergencies. Michael trained his dog not to bark at night.

verb If you train for a particular job, you learn how to do it. You go through the process of training. Bill is training as a mechanic. We had to train for a week before we were allowed to operate the machine.
verb If you train for a sports event, you make yourself physically fit by exercise and diet.

noun A train of events or thoughts is a connected sequence of them. Police asked the witness to describe the train of events that led up to the fight. A knock on the door interrupted my train of thought.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See training.adjective trained Bill's a trained mechanic.noun trainer

form.definition: noun A trainee is someone who is being taught how to do a particular job. Trainees are not permitted to do surgery unless a qualified surgeon is present.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb See train.adjective trainee ...a trainee teacher.

form.definition: noun Training is the process of getting prepared for a job or a sport. Have you had any training in staff management? She's had years of training as a singer. ...teacher training. ...toilet training.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb See train.

form.definition: noun A trait is a characteristic of someone's personality. His best traits are his kindness and sensitivity.

noun A traitor is someone who betrays their country, a friend or a group they belong to. After the war he was accused of being a traitor. Jean was a traitor to her friendshe began spreading rumours about her.
noun A tram is an electric passenger vehicle that runs on rails along the streets of a town.

verb If you trample something, you damage it by stepping heavily on it. The cows had trampled the grass under the tree. My handbag got trampled by the crowd. We trampled through the bush until we reached the track.

verb If you trample on someone's feelings or rights, you treat them in a harsh or unfair way. Alex is so insensitivehe just tramples on people's feelings. Low income earners claim they've been trampled on by the government.

adjective Something that is tranquil is calm and quiet. It is not disturbed by anything. He had a good, tranquil sleep after a hard day's work. The air was still and the water tranquil. His stay in Greece was the most tranquil period in his life.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See tranquilliser.noun tranquillity Come and enjoy the tranquillity of life on Magnetic Island.

form.definition: noun A tranquilliser is a drug for making anxious people feel calm.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING of this word is tranquillizer. ... WORD FAMILY verb tranquillise (<or> tranquillize) The horse was tranquillised by the injection the vet gave it.

dictionary.entry:
transfertrAns`f@:, tra:ns- for the verb; for the noun, ferredtransferring
verb If you transfer something, you move it from one place to another. We transferred our luggage from the trolley to the car. I've transferred the money from my cheque account into my savings account. Let's transfer our attention to more urgent matters.
verb If you transfer to a different job or place, or if someone transfers you, you are sent to a different job or place in the organisation that you work for. Mr Tanaka has transferred to the company's Melbourne branch. I've been transferred to accounts because of the staff shortage there.
noun A transfer is a design on a piece of paper which can be put onto another surface.
... WORD FAMILY noun transfer He's unhappy about his transfer to Melbourne. ...an electronic transfer.

form.definition: verb If something is transformed, it is completely changed, usually for the better. The warehouse has been transformed into a luxurious apartment. His skilful handling of the crisis has transformed my opinion of him.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun transformation

form.definition: noun If someone gives you a blood transfusion, they put blood into your body. James required a transfusion after the accident as he had lost a lot of blood.
adjective In grammar, a transitive verb is a verb that needs an object. For example, hit is a transitive verb because it must be followed by a noun that refers to the thing that is hit.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is intransitive.

form.definition: verb If you translate what someone has said or written, you say or write it in another language. We need someone to translate a document from Japanese into English.
verb If you translate one thing into another, you express it in a different form. People often talk of translat-ing ideas into action.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun translation An exact translation isn't necessary just a summary will do.

form.definition: verb If a signal or message is transmitted to a place, it is sent there by means of electronic equipment. The show will be transmitted live from our studio this evening. The bank is transmitting the money electronically. What's the quickest way to transmit the news to them?

verb If something is transmitted to a person or place, it passes on or is carried to that person or place. These customs have been transmitted from generation to generation. It's believed that the mad cows can transmit a deadly disease to humans. ...sexually transmitted diseases. ... WORD FAMILY noun transmission The rapid transmission of disease is linked with poor hygiene.

adjective An object or substance that is transparent allows light to pass through it and so you can see through it. We could see the bottom of the river through the transparent water. I can see where I'm going with my transparent plastic umbrella.

adjective If something is transparent, it can be easily understood, or there can be no doubt about it. I like the transparent style of the author's writing. The reason for his visit was not transparent. His charm and transparent honesty are rare.

dictionary.entry:
transplanttrAn`splAnt, tra:n- for the verb; for the `trAnsplAnt, `tra:n-
verb If you transplant something, you take it out of one place and move it to another. The shrub will need to be transplanted into the ground after a while. Doctors have transplanted marrow from a donor to the patient's spine.
noun A transplant is a surgical operation to replace part of a person's body that has stopped functioning properly. The patient will have to undergo a heart transplant.

transport`trAnsp@:t, `tra:n- for sense 1; for others,trAn`sp@:t, tra:n-
noun Transport is the process of moving people or goods from one place to another. The transport of goods from rural areas is becoming more efficient. Rail transport is cheaper than road transport.
... ANOTHER WORD for this is transportation.
noun Transport also refers to the vehicles you travel in, such as cars, boats and aeroplanes. She goes to work by public transport. We'll arrange a lift if you don't have your own transport.
verb If you transport people or goods, you move them from one place to another. This coal will be transported to a coastal port. 'How are you going to transport the cabinet to your house?' 'I'll put it on my trailer.'

traptrAptrapstrappedtrapping 1a noun A trap is a device for catching animals. The possum was caught in a trap. ...a mouse trap. b verb If you trap animals, you catch them using
noun A trap is also a plan to trick or deceive someone into doing something they don't want to do. The drug dealer arrived at the pub not suspecting there was a police trap.
verb If you trap a person, you trick or deceive them into doing something they don't want to do. They trapped the man into admitting what he had done.
verb If you are trapped in a place, you cannot move or get out of it. Firefighters tried to reach the people trapped inside the burning building.
noun A trap is also an unpleasant situation that it is difficult to get out of or change. Getting into debt is a real trap. b verb If you are trapped, you are in an unpleasant situation that it is difficult for you to get out of or change. Many families are trapped in the poverty cycle.
verb If something traps another thing such as dirt or water, it keeps it or holds it back within itself. The dam traps water from the nearby mountains. He cleaned out the dirt that was trapped in the drain.

form.definition: noun A trauma is a very distressing or shocking experience. He's never forgotten the trauma of being attacked by a shark. We're not ready for the joys and traumas of parenthood.
noun Trauma is the lasting emotional damage that is caused by a distressing or shocking experience.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective traumatic It was the most traumatic time in her life.

form.definition: verb If you travel, you go to a place or to several places. You take a trip somewhere. He travels to work by car. Last year we travelled around Europe. We travelled at 30 k per hour in pouring rain.
noun Travel is the act of travelling. Sandra hates overseas travelshe says it's too tiring.
verb You can say that something travels if it moves or goes somewhere. Can you make the ball travel in a straight line? The noise from upstairs travels right through the ceiling.
travels You can refer to the trips that you make when you are a long way from home as your travels. Ross bought some excellent wines on his recent travels around the country.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See travel agent.adjective travel ...a travel brochure. ...travel plans. ...a travel rug.noun traveller The tired travellers stopped at a motel.

form.definition: noun A travel agent is a person whose job is to arrange things like tickets and accommodation for people who want to travel. A travel agent works in a business or office called a travel agency.
noun A tray is a flat object with raised edges that's used for carrying food. Jan's husband brought her some tea on a tray.
adjective A treacherous person is disloyal or deceitful. They are likely to betray you.
adjective An area that is treacherous is dangerous or risky. Slow downthis is a treacherous part of the highway.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb treacherously Max behaved treacherously towards the company.

form.definition: noun Treachery is the act of betraying someone who trusts you. Max was sacked for his treachery in selling product information to a rival company.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See treacherous.

form.definition: verb If you tread on something, you step or stand on it. Carefuldon't tread on the broken glass. My new dancing partner keeps treading on my toes!

verb If you tread something into the ground or into a carpet, you crush or press it down with your feet. He trod the cigarette butt into the ground.
