Over the years they'd trodden a lot of crumbs into the carpet around the table. 3a verb If you tread in a particular way, you walk along in that way. Tread softly or you'll wake the baby.
noun Someone's tread is the way they walk or the sound they make as they walk. Ken walks with a heavy treadthat's him now.
noun The tread of a tyre is the part which touches the road. It has ridges on it to prevent it from slipping.
noun Treasure is a collection of valuable objects such as jewels and things made of gold and silver. Workers discovered buried treasure on the building site.
verb If you treasure something, you think of it as being precious. It is valuable to you. Brian has always treasured that photo of you. I treasure our friendshipyou mean a lot to me.
noun An art treasure is a very valuable work of art. Pollock's 'Blue Poles' is one of Australia's most important art treasures.
noun A treasurer is a person who is in charge of the finances of a club or a society.

verb If you treat someone in a certain way, you behave towards them that way. He always treats people with kindness and respect. We were shocked to see how badly the animals were being treated. Don't treat me as a childI'm an adult now.

verb If you treat something in a certain way, you consider it in that way or you handle it in that way. He treated his business trip as a bit of a holiday. Please treat library books with care. Don't treat what he says too seriously.

verb When a doctor treats a patient or an illness, he or she tries to make a patient well by giving them medical care. The hospital is treating fifty people with severe burns. There's still no effective way to treat the common cold. Ken was treated for shock and minor injuries.
verb If you treat something such as wood, you put a particular substance on it to protect it. We've treated the wood with termite repellent. Have these vegetables been treated with insecticide?

noun If you give someone a treat, you give them something special that they will enjoy. It is usually food or entertainment that is not always available. The kids always get some kind of treat when they visit grandma. Going away for the weekend was a real treat for us.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun treatment Their treatment of the animals is cruel. He's having treatment for burns.verb treat Grandma treated the kids to some lamingtons.[qr

dictionary.entry:
treetri:
noun A tree is a tall plant with a thick, hard stem and with branches and leaves.

form.definition: verb If your body or part of your body trembles, it shakes slightly, usually because you're cold, weak or afraid. If your voice trembles, it sounds unsteady. My hands were trembling with the cold. Her voice trembled as she spoke.
verb If something trembles, it shakes slightly. The leaves trembled in the wind.

adjective If you describe something as tremendous, you mean that it is extremely large or important. On the way home we were caught in a tremendous storm. The party was a tremendous success. Raising children is a tremendous responsibility.

adjective You can also say that something is tremendous if you think it is excellent or wonderful. Mark's a tremendous tennis player. 'How was your day at the zoo?' 'Really tremendousthe kids had a great time.'

noun A trend is a general direction or pattern in the way something develops. Today's trend is towards less fatty food. Poor writing skills is a disturbing new trend among tertiary students. He follows closely the latest trends in computer technology.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See trendy.

form.definition: adjective A trendy person or thing is fashionable or stylish. Her clothes are trendy but inexpensive. There were a lot of trendy art students at the exhibition.

verb If you trespass on someone's land or property, you enter it without their permission. The boys were caught trespassing on a building site. Foreign fishing boats often trespass into Australian waters.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun trespasser TRESPASSERS WILL BE PROSECUTED

form.definition: noun A trial is a court case in which a judge and a jury listen to evidence about a particular crime and decide if the person accused of it is innocent or guilty. The trial ended in an acquittal. Watson is on trial for manslaughter.
noun A trial is also a period of testing the quality or performance of an object. Initial trials suggest that the new drug has no damaging side-effects.
3 trial run A trial run is a first attempt at using something to see if it works properly. Why don't you take the car for a trial run?[qr

dictionary.entry:
triangle`tra:IANgl
noun A triangle is a geometric figure with three straight sides and three angles.
... WORD FAMILY adjective triangular

form.definition: noun A tribunal is a group of people officially appointed to deal with certain problems. The employee approached the industrial relations tribunal with his complaint against his boss. ...a rent tribunal.
verb If someone tricks you, they deceive you, usually in order to make you do something. Sandra felt that the salesman had tricked her into buying the car.
noun A trick is something a person does in order to deceive someone. Can you think of a trick that will make him let us in for nothing? Let's play a trick on Paul.
noun A trick is a skilful act that someone does to entertain people. The clown's tricks delighted the audience. Can your dog do any tricks?

noun A trick is an effective or clever way of doing something. There's a trick to opening these jarslet me show you. If you want fast service the trick is to have your papers ready when you get in the queue.
verb If a liquid trickles somewhere, it drops or flows in a slow, thin stream. Blood kept trickling out of the cut in my finger.

verb If people or things trickle somewhere, they come or go somewhere slowly or gradually. Towards the end of the movie people started trickling out of the cinema. Donations are starting to trickle in for the building restoration fund.
verb Tried is the past tense and past participle of try.

verb If you trim something such as your hair or a shrub, you cut small amounts off the ends of it, usually to make it look tidier. I've just had my hair trimmed. The gardener trims the grass every fortnight.
adjective If someone is trim, they are slim or elegant. Tony's always had a trim figure.
adjective If something is trim, it is tidy. Their garden always looks trim.
verb If you trim a piece of clothing or fabric, you add something to the edge of it in order to decorate it. Alice trimmed the blouse with matching lace.
noun A trip is a journey that you make to and from a place. How was your trip to central Australia? Stan makes several business trips every year.
verb If you trip, your foot gets caught on something while you are walking, and you fall over or nearly fall over. The boy tripped and fell. I tripped over a mat at the entrance to the shop.
verb If you trip someone, you make their foot get caught on something so that they fall over or nearly fall over.
adjective Triple means having three parts. This food processor has a triple function: it mixes, cuts and extracts juice.

verb If you triple something or if it triples, it becomes three times bigger in amount or number than it was before. The doctor advised me to triple the amount of vegetables I eat. Our company's profits have tripled in the last five years.
noun A triumph is a great achievement, victory or success. The new building is one of the triumphs of modern architecture. The team achieved a complete triumph over its opponents.
noun Triumph is the feeling of joy or satisfaction when you achieve or win something. Richard gave a shout of triumph when he won the lottery.

verb If you triumph, you succeed in overcoming some difficulty or you achieve something. It was a long and hard struggle, but he triumphed in the end. Look at him up therehe's certainly triumphed over his fear of heights.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective triumphant adverb triumphantly

form.definition: adjective If something is trivial, it is unimportant. She seemed more interested in the trivial details than the general point I was making.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun triviality Don't waste time on such trivialities.

form.definition: verb Trod is the past tense of tread.
verb Trodden is the past participle of tread.[qr

dictionary.entry:
trolley`trOli:
noun A trolley is a small vehicle on wheels that you use to carry heavy things. You push or pull it along by hand. ...a supermarket trolley. ...a tea trolley. ...a luggage trolley.

form.definition: noun Troops are soldiers who are involved in military action. The troops have just returned from a peace keeping operation in Africa.
noun A troop of people is a large crowd of them moving around. ...a troop of shoppers. ...a troop of school children.
verb If people troop somewhere, they walk there together in a large group. The children all trooped down the stairs after their teacher.
adjective If a place or thing is described as tropical, it is found in the tropics or comes from the tropics. Sugar cane is grown in the tropical areas of Queensland. Do you like tropical fruit?
noun The tropics are the region near the equator that has the hottest climate in the world.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See tropical.

form.definition: noun Trouble or troubles are problems, worry, pain, difficulty, and so on. She's had a life of trouble and sorrow. The boy got into trouble in the surf and had to be rescued. The trouble with this computer is that it's too slow. ...marriage troubles.
noun If you have trouble doing something, you have difficulty doing it. Did you have any trouble understanding the lecture? We had a lot of trouble finding the placeit wasn't on the map.

noun If you have heart trouble or trouble with your hearing, there is something wrong with your heart or with your hearing. She has to watch what she eats because of stomach trouble. He got back trouble from lifting heavy things.

noun If it is trouble for someone to do something, it is not convenient or it requires a lot of effort for them to do it. The conference was a success but organising it was more trouble than I expected. If it's no trouble, could you give me a lift home?
verb If something troubles you, it makes you feel upset or worried. The boy's parents are very troubled by his lack of enthusiasm. What troubles me is that we may not finish on time.

noun If there is trouble, people are fighting or arguing. I'm having trouble with the neighbours again. Some drunken youths were causing trouble in the pub. The sackings could lead to industrial trouble.

verb In rather formal language, you can use trouble when you want to ask someone to do something for you. If you apologise for troubling someone, you are apologising for disturbing them so that you can ask them something. May I trouble you to post this letter for me? Can I trouble you for the salt and pepper? Sorry to trouble you again, but could you sign these cheques, please?

in trouble If someone is in trouble, they are blamed for doing something wrong, or someone in authority thinks they have done something wrong. Her son's in trouble with the police for car theft. I'll phone you after workI don't want to get you in trouble for wasting time on the phone.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective troubled There was a troubled expression on his face.adjective troubling They've just received the troubling news that they've been burgled.

form.definition: noun Trousers are a piece of clothing that covers both legs separately and reaches from the waist to the ankles.
form.note: ... NOTE that before a noun the form trouser is used, for example trouser pocket.

form.definition: noun A truck is a large motor vehicle used for carrying heavy loads of goods, usually over long distances.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is lorry.

form.definition: verb If you trudge somewhere, you walk there slowly and with heavy steps. We trudged home after an exhausting day of football. The hikers trudged five kilometres through muddy terrain.

adjective A true statement is based on facts and on real events. I didn't know whether to believe him or not, but he assured me the story was true. Is it true you're going overseas soon? Emus can fly. True or false?

adjective If you describe something as true, you mean that it has all the features of a particular thing and is rightly called what it is called. It is genuine or real. You're a true hero. My grandfather was a true Italian farmer. He always hides his true feelings. ...true love.
come true If a prediction or wish comes true, it actually happens. Her wish came true when she won the overseas holiday.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See truth.adverb truly He was truly sorry for what he did.

form.definition: noun A trumpet is a brass musical instrument. You play it by blowing into it and pressing its three buttons.
noun The trunk of a tree is the thick main stem from which the branches grow.
noun Your trunk is the main central part of your body apart from your head, arms and legs.
noun An elephant's trunk is its very long nose.

verb If you trust someone, you believe they are honest and that you can depend on them. It's hard to trust people who keep breaking promises. He's dishonestI wouldn't trust him. You have to trust your own judgment.
noun Trust is the belief or willingness to believe that you can rely on something or someone. Our trust in the legal system has been shaken. I'm putting my trust in the surgeon's skill.

verb If you trust someone to do something, you depend on them to do it properly or safely. Jenny trusts her children to go to the shops by themselves. Are you sure you can trust him with all that money?
noun Trust is a responsibility that has been given to you. Parents should not betray their children's trust.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See trustworthy.

form.definition: adjective If someone is trustworthy, you can trust them because they behave in a responsible or reliable way. Trish is a trustworthy friend.

noun The truth is the facts about something, rather than lies or things that are invented or imagined. 'That's a lie.' 'No, it's the truthI saw what happened myself.' The truth was that Fred had lost the money through gambling.
noun A truth is a fact or belief that is generally accepted as true. The book if full of wonderful truths for children to learn. It's a sad truth that many people around the world live in poverty.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See truthful.

form.definition: adjective If you are truthful, you tell the truth. You are honest. James has always been a truthful child. I believe what he's told us.
adjective A truthful statement is true. It was a truthful account of what happened but no-one seemed to believe it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb truthfully

form.definition: verb If you try to do something that you want to do, you make an effort to do it. He tried to fix it but failed. Please try to get it done today. I'm trying to lose weight. Try and do it by yourself. We'll try and get there early.

verb If you try something, you do it or use it to find out how good or useful it is. Have you ever tried making your own bread? He tried two phones before he found one that worked. Let's try a different cheese.

verb If you try a place or person, you go to that place or person because you think you could get something you want from them. I can't answer your question but why don't you try Ianhe's an expert on the subject. He tried the hardware store but they didn't have what he needed.
verb If someone is tried, they go to a court, and a judge and jury decides if they are guilty of a crime that they have been accused of. Matt was arrested and tried in the District Court for assault.
verb If you try a door or window, you make an effort to open it.
try on If you try on a piece of clothing, you put it on to see if it fits you or looks good on you. Bart tried on the trousers but they were too short.
try out If you try something out, you test it by using or experiencing it. The company is trying out a new approach to improving sales.
noun A T-shirt is a piece of clothing that you wear on the top part of your body. It has short sleeves, no collar and no buttons, and is usually made of a light, stretchy fabric.
noun A tube is a long, round, hollow pipe used for liquids or gases to move through. The patient was being fed intravenously through a plastic tube.

noun A tube is a container for some thick substance such as glue or toothpaste. It has a hole in one end through which you squeeze out the substance. ...a tube of toothpaste. ...a tube of paint. ...a tube of hand cream.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective tubular The chair had tubular, metal legs.

form.definition: verb If you tuck one thing such as cloth or paper into another, you push or fold the loose edges of it inside the other thing so that it looks tidy. Tuck your shirt into your trousers. The sheets were tucked firmly under the mattress.

verb If you tuck something somewhere, you press it into a place where it will be safe. 'Where do you want these tea towels to go?' 'Just tuck them into the top drawer.' He tucked the stamps into a flap in his wallet.
noun Tuesday is one of the seven days of the week. It comes after Monday and before Wednesday.
noun A tuft is a cluster of something such as grass or hair held closely together. The children were picking tufts of grass to give to the horses.
verb If you tug something or at something, you pull it with quick, strong movements. The boy kept tugging at his mother's sleeve to get her attention.
noun A tug is a small, powerful boat that pulls large boats or ships up rivers or inside a harbour.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun tug The drawer will open if you give it a tug.

form.definition: noun Tuition is the teaching of a subject, especially to one person or to a small group. Claire's having private tuition in music theory.
verb If you tumble, you fall with a circular or rolling movement. William tumbled off his bicycle as he turned the corner.

verb If something tumbles, it falls or rolls along quickly. The pile of books came tumbling down as I reached for it. The rainwater carried rubbish with it as it tumbled along the gutters. The temperature tumbled to 5 degrees at night.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun tumble adjective tumble ...a tumble dryer.

form.definition: noun A tumour is a mass of diseased tissue growing in or on part of the body. ...a cancerous tumour. ...a benign tumour.
noun A tuna is a large sea fish that is eaten as food. 'Do you like raw tuna?' 'Yes, it's delicious. I like canned tuna too.'
form.note: ... NOTE that tuna is both the singular and the plural form of this word.

form.definition: noun A tune is a series of musical sounds occurring one after the other, usually in a pleasant pattern. She whistled a tune as she drove home. The main tune in the first movement is played by the clarinet.
verb If you tune a musical instrument, you adjust it so that it makes the right sounds.

verb If you tune an engine, television or radio, you adjust it so that it works properly. When did you last have the engine tuned? If you tune the TV you'll get a better picture. My radio's always tuned to Radio National.
in tune or out of tune If a musical instrument is in tune, it is adjusted so that it makes the right sounds. If it is out of tune, it doesn't make the right sounds.
noun A tunnel is a long, underground passage, usually made under the sea or through a hill.
verb If someone or something tunnels somewhere, they make a tunnel. The wombat tunnelled through to the other side of the road.
noun Turkish is the standard language spoken in Turkey.
adjective If someone or something comes from Turkey, you describe them as Turkish.

verb If you turn something or when it turns, it moves around a particular point. It keeps moving around, or it stops and faces in a different direction. The wheels of the bicycle were turning quickly. The chef turned the chicken on its back. He turned the page and saw the ad. The key doesn't turnit's stuck.

verb If you turn, you change the position of your body so that you face in a different direction. He turned to look at the clock. The shop was closed so we turned and went back. He turned away and pretended not to notice me.

verb If you turn in a particular direction or turn a corner, you change the direction in which you are moving. Turn right at the intersection. The taxi turned the corner and picked up a passenger. The river turns east at the bottom of the mountain.
verb If you turn a handle, knob, key, and so on, you twist it with your hand in order to control or start something. She turned the key to start the car.
turn on If you turn on something such as a light, TV or heater, you make it start working by moving the knob or switch that controls it.
adjective Something that is turquoise is a greenish-blue colour. She wore a turquoise jumper.
noun Turquoise is a rather valuable stone used in jewellery. It is a greenish-blue colour.
noun A tutor is a teacher, especially one who teaches in a university or gives private lessons to individuals.
noun TV is short for television. A TV is a television set. Don't sit so close to the TV. Is there anything worth watching on TV tonight?
noun Tweezers are a small tool for picking up or pulling out very small things such as hairs. He got the splinter out of his finger with a pair of tweezers.
adjective The twelfth person or thing is the one which comes next in order after the eleventh.
noun A twelfth is one of twelve equal parts of something.
noun Twelve is the number 12, ten plus two.
adjective If you have twelve things, the number of things you have adds up to twelve.
adjective The twentieth person or thing is the one which comes next in order after the nineteenth.
noun A twentieth is one of twenty equal parts of something.
noun Twenty is the number 20, ten times two.
adjective If you have twenty things, the number of things you have adds up to twenty.
adverb If something happens twice, it happens two times. Margaret plays tennis twice a week. Doug's been to Perth twice.

adverb If something is twice as good or big as another thing, or if it is twice the quantity, size, speed, age, and so on, as another thing, it is two times as good or big, and so on, as the other thing. Their house is twice as big as ours. Tim runs twice as fast as his brother. You've eaten twice as much as the others. Her car was twice the price of mine. She's twice his age.
noun A twig is a small, thin branch that grows out of a larger branch of a tree or shrub.
noun Twilight is the time after sunset before it gets very dark.
noun If two people are twins, they have the same mother and were born at the same time.
noun A twin is also one of two similar or matching things.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective twin ...a twin sister or brother. ...twin beds.

form.definition: noun A twinge is a sudden, sharp pain. As she leaned forward she felt a twinge in her left shoulder.
noun If you have a twinge of an unpleasant emotion, you suddenly feel that emotion intensely for a moment. He felt a twinge of regret about selling the house.
verb If a light or a star twinkles, it shines with a light that keeps changing from bright to faint. The city lights twinkled in the background as we sat in the restaurant.
verb If your eyes twinkle, they show that you are happy or amused about something. ... WORD FAMILY noun twinkle Her joke brought a twinkle to his eye.

verb If you twist something or if it twists, one end of it moves or turns in one direction while the other end turns in the opposite direction or remains in the same position. She twisted the end of the plastic bag and tied a knot in it. He twisted around to see who was sitting behind him.
2 verb If something twists or is twisted, it bends or moves out of its natural shape. The hose got twisted and tangled as it was dragged around the yard. Her face was twisted in pain.
verb If you twist part of your body such as your wrist or ankle, you injure it by turning it too far in an unusual direction. Ted twisted his ankle when he jumped off the bus.
verb If you twist something, you turn it around in a circular direction. You rotate it. Twist the knob to the left. She twisted the lid off the jar.
verb If a river or road twists, it has sharp turns or bends along it.
verb If you twist what someone has said, you change the intended meaning of it. She always manages to twist my words to make me look like a fool.
noun A twist in a story or situation is an unexpected event, often occurring at the end. There's a strange twist to the plot near the end of the movie.
twist someone's arm If you twist someone's arm, you forcefully persuade them to do something.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun twist Give the knob a twist. We came to a twist in the road.adjective twisted The car was a mass of twisted metal.

form.definition: noun Two is the number 2, one plus one.
adjective If you have two things, the number of things you have adds up to two. We have two children, a girl and a boy.
verb Tying is the present participle of tie.

noun A type of something is a particular group or class of it. The things that belong to this group share certain qualities that are not shared by things that are outside this group. What type of car do you have, a sedan or a station wagon? Scientists keep developing new types of plastic. A squash is a type of vegetable. What's your blood type?

noun You can refer to something as a particular type if you think of it as being related to other things with similar qualities. This type of work doesn't suit herit's too repetitive. That's the type of nonsense you'd expect from him.

noun In rather informal language, you can say someone is a particular type when you are describing their appearance or character. I'm afraid I'm not the sport-loving type. He's typical of the trendy type you find in these cafes. Mark's an easygoing typeyou'll like him.
verb If you type something, you write it using a typewriter or word processor. Would you please type this letter for me as soon as possible.

noun Type is the style or size of printed letters that is used in a typed or printed document, such as a magazine or book. Bold type is used in this textbook to highlight important words. ...italic type.
not your type In informal language, if you say that someone is not your type, you mean that they are not the kind of person you consider to be interesting or attractive.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun typing Could you do some typing for me, please?adjective typing What's your typing speed? Typing skills are essential these days.

form.definition: noun A typewriter is a machine that produces writing in print by means of keys that you press with your fingers.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective typewritten Send us your typewritten resume by the due date.

form.definition: noun Typhoid is a serious infectious disease that affects the intestines causing fever and often death.
noun A typhoon is a violent tropical storn that occurs in the western Pacific.

adjective Something that is typical of a particular group or class of things has the main signs or the distinctive qualities of that group of things. We spent the weekend in a typical country town. The weather was typical of an Australian summervery hot and dry. A typical day at the office starts with looking at the mail.
adjective If someone's behaviour is typical of them, it is their usual behaviour. Is it typical of him to keep people waiting? He spoke with typical frankness.

adverb You can say that something typically happens in a particular way if it usually happens in that way. She typically visits his mother once a fortnight. These birds typically have yellow feathers.
adverb You can use typically to indicate that something has all the main signs or distinctive qualities of a particular group or class of things. A barbecue is a typically Australian social event.

noun A tyre is a thick band of rubber filled with air and fitted around the outside edge of a wheel, especially on a car or bicycle. Make sure you check your tyres before you set off on your trip, and don't forget to take a spare tyre. ...a bicycle tyre. ...a flat tyre.[fa[xp
